PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned are deeply concerned at the impact of the new Fringe Benefits Tax on the following grounds:
1.-its severe and damaging effect on business confidence, investment and incentive, especially in the rural, mining and small business sectors.
2.-its capacity to seriously worsen unemployment through the additional costs it imposes.
3.-its extremely negative impact on the competitiveness of export industries at a time when the nation desperately needs to improve its trading performance.

4.-in that it may compel many honest and decent citizens to defy tax in order to preserve their livelihoods, their businesses and the jobs of their employees thus causing hardship, the breakdown of respect for the law and discord within the community.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation

That we oppose utterly the proposed Bill of Rights because this Bill will
Transfer to government powers not given nor intended to be given by the Constitution
Threaten our rights by making them subject to the will of this and any future Government

Set the State above the individual

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION ADMINISTRATION AMENDMENT (RECOVERY OF TAX DEBTS) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill proposes amendments of a safeguarding nature that are made necessary by a decision of the Full Court of the Queensland Supreme Court in an action by a Deputy Commissioner of Taxation to recover an unpaid taxation debt.

The Court, by majority, held that the time limits specified in the Queensland Limitation of Actions Act 1974 for the commencement of proceedings to recover a debt applied, by virtue of section 64 of the Commonwealth Judiciary Act 1903, to proceedings to recover taxation debts to the Commonwealth.

The decision, contrary to decisions previously taken by supreme courts in Western Australia and New South Wales, is contrary to the long held view that taxation debts could, by virtue of the crown prerogative, be recovered at any time.
The Commissioner of Taxation has applied to the High Court for special leave to appeal against the decision of the Queensland Supreme Court.

The effect of the Queensland decision unless reversed by the High Court is that, in that State, the commencement of an action for the recovery of tax is subject to a six-year limitation period and the commencement of an action to recover additional tax for late payment is subject to a two-year limitation period.
Mr President, this decision has extremely serious revenue implications both for this year's Budget and for future Budgets.

Unless prompt legislative action is taken, the recovery of many millions of dollars of outstanding tax, mainly from tax avoiders, will at best be delayed for several months and, at worst, prevented altogether.
If the rationale for the decision were to apply Australia-wide, revenue of the order of $200m would be placed in jeopardy in 1986-87.
A further $700m would be at risk in later years.
This particular revenue loss simply cannot be countenanced.
Not to act without delay to protect the revenue would be irresponsible.
The vast majority of the $900m is owed by tax avoidance participants of the 1970s and early 1980s.

Over the past 5 to 10 years, they have resorted to every means available to frustrate the considerable efforts of the Commissioner of Taxation to resolve disputes as to liability and to secure the payment of outstanding tax and penalties.

To delay the action now proposed would reward these tax avoiders for the frustration they have caused and would be completely out of step with this Government's commitment to ensure that such people do not escape their financial obligations to all Australians.
The amendment proposed by this Bill is a fair and sensible one.

It will mean that, where liability for a taxation debt is, or has been, disputed, the period during which an action for the recovery of the debt may be commenced will correspondingly be extended by the time taken to resolve the dispute.
In a case where there is no dispute, the time limits specified in any applicable State or Territory limitation law will apply according to that law.
The proposed amendment will, however, apply only if State or Territory limitation laws are ultimately held by the High Court to apply to the recovery of Commonwealth taxation debts.

A further measure contained in the Bill will treat penalty taxes for late lodgment of tax returns, making of false or misleading statements or participation in tax avoidance schemes as ordinary debts for limitation law purposes.

This will mean that these penalty taxes will be subject to the generally longer limitation period that applies to the recovery of ordinary debts, rather than the shorter period that applies to the recovery of penalties.
The amendments will apply to actions for the recovery of taxation debts whether incurred before or after the Bill becomes law.
In this respect the Bill is if the Queensland Supreme Court is correct in its decision, technically retrospective in application.
But-and I emphasise this-it does not retrospectively impose any new or increased tax liability or make unlawful any conduct.
The Bill does no more than any responsible government, faced with a revenue loss of $900m, would be compelled to do in the face of a decision such as that taken by the Queensland Supreme Court.

The proposed amendments will not, however, apply to proceedings for the recovery of a tax debt where a court has, on or before today, given a decision in such proceedings based on the application of a limitation law.

In other words, it will not apply to several cases recently decided by the Queensland Supreme Court, nor to one case presently subject to an appeal by the taxpayer to the New South Wales Court of Appeal.
Mr President, an explanatory memorandum which gives more details of the measures contained in the Bill is being circulated for the information of honourable senators.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: INSPECTOR-GENERAL OF INTELLIGENCE AND SECURITY BILL 1986AUSTRALIAN SECURITY INTELLIGENCE ORGANIZATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986INTELLIGENCE AND SECURITY (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 9 October.
INSPECTOR-GENERAL OF INTELLIGENCE AND SECURITY BILL 1986
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Briefly, we persist in our opposition to the amendments moved by Senator Durack. We think it is more desirable to have some check on the operations of our security services insofar as they affect the violation of human rights. We believe that the solution that we have come up with is the most satisfactory one and hence we oppose the amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Page 5, sub-clause 8 (1), leave out paragraph (d).
This amendment leaves out the last of the Inspector-General's functions as stated in clause 8 (1) of the Bill. Paragraph (d) reads:
where the responsible Minister has given a direction to ASIO on the question whether-
(i) the collection of intelligence concerning a particular individual is, or is not, justified by reason of its relevance to security; or
(ii) the communication of intelligence concerning a particular individual would be for a purpose relevant to security,
to inquire into whether that collection is justified on that ground or whether that communication would be for that purpose . . .

Admittedly this is a rather unsatisfactory way of dealing with this issue, because the substantive provisions concerning the powers of the Minister to give these directions are contained in the Australian Security Intelligence Organisations Amendment Bill. In order to deal with them under the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Bill I will have to refer to the ASIO Bill. It might cut matters short if we debate this amendment in that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no problem with that at all. You can refer to the other Bill if it is necessary to explain this amendment.

—One of the major amendments to the ASIO legislation is contained in the amendments to section 8 of the existing Act, which appear in clause 5 of the ASIO Amendment Bill. Clause 5 lays out a new code for the relationship between the Minister and ASIO which is significantly different from that which appears in the 1979 legislation. In that legislation, section 8 provides that the Organisation should be under the control of the Director-General. It is not proposed to amend that provision. The section goes on to state that the Director-General is subject to the general directions of the Minister but that the Minister is not empowered to override the opinion of the Director-General on the question of the collection of intelligence concerning a particular individual or on the question of a communication of intelligence about a particular individual.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's changes to the ASIO Act, which follow consequentially in the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Bill, specifically propose that the Director-General be subject to the directions of the Minister and not just to general directions. The Director-General can request the Minister to put those directions in writing. The provision goes on to say that the Minister is not empowered to override the opinion of the Director-General concerning the nature of the advice that should be given. That follows the existing legislation and we have no problem with that. The main problem is sub-clause (5), which states that the Minister is not empowered to override the opinion of the Director-General on the question of collecting intelligence about individuals or communicating that intelligence except by a direction contained in an instrument in writing that sets out the Minister's reasons for overriding the opinion. Sub-clause (6) states:
The Minister shall, as soon as practicable after giving a direction in writing to the Director-General, cause a copy of the direction to be given to the Inspector-General . . .

A copy is also to be forwarded to the Prime Minister, in certain circumstances. Subsequently the Bill gives the Inspector-General the function of considering the propriety of a Minister's direction to collect intelligence about a particular individual or to communicate that intelligence. There is also in clause 35 of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Bill a provision for the Inspector-General in his annual report to report on that matter to the Prime Minister. The approach in this new code is completely different from that adopted in the Act. This is one of our main objections to the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Amendment Bill, against which we voted on second reading. We maintain our objection to this legislation because of this change in the relationship between the Minister and the Organization.

This is a difficult matter and deals with the sensitive issues. The existing provision was designed to preserve human rights and civil liberties, about which we have heard so much from the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) and from the Australian Democrats. But instead of waffle, generalisations and trigger words relating to human rights, the principal Act contains a specific way of protecting individual and human rights. It seeks to prevent the abuse of power by a Minister, Prime Minister or a government in seeking to use the security services for political ends. If this amending legislation is passed, they can do just that, whereas the existing provisions provide a shield for the Director-General and his Organisation to refuse to comply with a ministerial direction to investigate a particular individual or, more seriously, that it should give the Minister concerned information on a particular individual.

This is probably the most dangerous area of abuse of the security system by a government and should not be allowed, and it is covered in section 8 of the Act. But the proposals in this legislation will completely change that provision and, in a dressed-up way, are designed to obscure the reality of the fact that a new, dangerous power is being given to the Minister to use the Organisation for political purposes. Clearly, there are temptations for governments to use and misuse the sort of information obtained by security services in the proper course of their work; they may well obtain information that is politically sensitive. If a Minister can misuse the Organisation for political purposes, as he is virtually invited to do by this amending legislation, we are concerned that he may do so. There is an extraordinary contradiction in the approach to this legislation.

We have all sorts of new proposals based presumably on the fact that we cannot really trust Ministers to exercise their responsibility. We have to set up a parliamentary committee and we have to appoint an Inspector-General because ministerial control presumably, in the eyes of the Government, is inadequate. At the same time as the Government is doing that, it is proposing to give a great new and highly dangerous instrument of ministerial abuse of the organisation for political purposes. No doubt we will hear the Minister say: `But that cannot be abused because the Inspector-General will look at this proposal, he will report to the Prime Minister about it, and the Prime Minister may tell the Parliament about it'. How utterly naive that proposal is.

The Inspector-General has no power to stop this abuse. If the Government were really dinkum about this it would give the Inspector-General the power. A Minister or a Prime Minister-let us not put any greater faith necessarily in the Prime Minister than in the Attorney-General-could be intent upon abusing this power. If the Government were really serious about this, it would give the Inspector-General the right to stop that abuse effectively by restraining them from abusing that power in a direct way, such as the right to proceed to a court. But no, the Government has not done that. The Inspector-General can simply tell the Prime Minister that he thinks something is an abuse of power. What a joke that is. The probability is that, if the Attorney-General were trying to get information on somebody, the Prime Minister would be up to his neck in it as well. There would not be much assurance that the Prime Minister would do anything about it. The Government says: `But the Inspector-General has to put this in his report'. Whom does he report to? He reports to the Prime Minister. It could be said that clause 35 of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Bill states that this report goes to Parliament. Clause 35 states in relation to presenting the report to Parliament:

the Prime Minister may make such deletions from a report . . . as the Prime Minister considers necessary in order to avoid prejudice to security, the defence of Australia, Australia's relations with other countries or the privacy of individuals.

So the Prime Minister could very neatly delete from his report to the Parliament what the Inspector-General may have said about something with which the Prime Minister disagrees, if he and the Attorney-General were trying to get information for political purposes.

We simply cannot have it both ways. If we do not trust the system of ministerial responsibility in relation to these security services we should not be giving, as this provision does, power to the Minister and to the Prime Minister to abuse utterly individuals' civil and human rights by collecting information and using it for political purposes. That is the basis of this amendment. It is the basis of a range of amendments to two of the Bills. If we are to take this amendment as the test of whether we believe that scheme should be introduced, I hope that the Committee rejects these proposals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Government I reject the Opposition's amendment. I also reject strongly some of the assertions that have been made. As I have pointed out before, Opposition members gave considerable weight during the second reading debate to the report of the Hope Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies, but once they got to the substance of the debate there were two areas in which they disregarded the recommendations and advice of Mr Justice Hope. These areas are the appointment of the Inspector-General and increased ministerial control. We now find that Government members are turning to Mr Justice Hope for support. It is not the Government that is having things both ways, but the Opposition. Opposition members want to use Mr Justice Hope's report in a general way, then selectively they want to disregard what he has to say. If, as Senator Durack says, the Government is being naive in this area then Mr Justice Hope is also being naive in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: It is unfortunate that the shadow Attorney-General should accuse the Government of having base motives in this debate. I do not intend to raise the emotional level or the heat of the debate, but I think it is unfortunate that that should have happened. We are all aware that we have a difficult job in providing a balance between the proper political control and direction of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, which Senator Macklin talked about, and avoiding undue interference which could lead to the very bad situation, mentioned by Senator Durack, in which ASIO becomes a tool of the Government or, even worse, of the Minister, as has happened in some countries.
On page 314 of his report on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, Mr Justice Hope says in paragraph 16.32:
. . . there is considerable validity in the submission that the responsibility of the Minister to the Parliament justifies him in having a concern about these matters--
that is, the direction in which ASIO is going. He goes on:
To prevent him altogether from overriding the opinion of the Director-General derogates from the Minister's ability fully to be responsible.
The Minister must have the capacity to be responsible, responsible to the Parliament and the people of this country. Mr Justice Hope goes on:

Likewise, although his responsibility would usually be satisfied by giving general rather than particular directions, the Minister's inability to give a particular direction may also impose an inappropriate limitation on his ability to carry out his responsibility.
He goes on to give illustrations and then on page 319 he makes the recommendations that led to this section of the legislation.

In our view, the Attorney-General should be able to override the Director-General, but not without some protection against the interference that Senator Durack has rightly said occurs in some countries. We need to ensure that the Attorney-General has someone keeping an eye on him and on his activities in this area. Hence, in line with Mr Hope's recommendations, we have provided in this legislation greater ministerial control than before, but also greater ministerial responsibility and accountability. In the performance of his functions under the Act, the Director-General is subject to the directions of the Minister, rather than general directions which is the way the existing legislation goes. However, the Minister cannot override the opinion of the Director-General on the question of whether the collection or communication of intelligence concerning a particular individual would be connected with security. If he does so, if he makes directions, he must do so in writing and those directions must go to the Prime Minister and the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security. An edited copy of the Inspector-General's report also goes each year to the Leader of the Opposition under clause 35 (3) of the legislation. Thus we have a whole series of checks and balances against the abuse of power by the Attorney-General.

Whether Senator Durack likes it or not, we are a democracy and we are trying to retain that democracy. Parliament, Ministers and Prime Ministers have a responsibility. The piece of legislation in this clause takes into account the concerns of the community, and Mr Justice Hope, that this organisation, like any other organisation, should be seen to be responsible but at the same time not be shackled by such responsibility. The Government believes the legislation maintains the balance between proper political control and ensuring that there is no undue interference. For that reason the sorts of fearful consequences that Senator Durack implies could occur will not occur. They could occur only with the agreement of the Prime Minister, the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security, the Leader of the Opposition and the Director-General of ASIO. In those circumstances I think Senator Durack is drawing a very long bow in his concern about this legislation. We will persist in our opposition to his amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats do not support the amendment moved by the Opposition. I think it is a pity that Senator Durack in his contribution on this clause decided to resort to some well-worn political tactics instead of addressing the basic legal and political issue involved in terms of directions of security services in a democratic society. It seems to us that the move made in this clause by the Government is appropriate. As the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) has pointed out, if Senator Durack's scenario were to get off the ground it would need the connivance of a range of people in the security world as well as people in the political world. That would strain the intelligence and imagination of most people, but obviously not of Senator Durack. The proposition that we are looking at is in clause 5 (6) of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Amendment Bill, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister shall as soon as practicable after having given a direction in writing to the Director-General, cause a copy of the direction to be given to the Inspector-General of Security and, if the direction relates to a question referred to in sub-section (5) to the Prime Minister.

It seems to me to be appropriate in a democratic society that those people who are responsible to the people for ordering the well-being of the country have control over such agencies and organisations operating on behalf of the country. Without that type of control I believe we would find ourselves in the types of situations that the United States of America has found itself in, with intelligence agencies out of control. The Soviet Union on occasions has found its intelligence agencies out of control. For some reason that entirely escapes me, it seems that bad will is always to be attributed to political leaders and good will always to be attributed to an agency of the government. That is an absurd proposition when put in that way. That seems to me to be the import of the contribution that Senator Durack made. Fairly obviously, there can be bad will in both areas and good will in both areas. What we are attempting to do is to get the right balance so that there are checks and balances.

In terms of political theory, checks and balances should be established and developed within democratic societies so that absolute power does not reside in any particular spot and there are recourses. For example, the Prime Minister and Cabinet do not have untrammelled power; they are answerable to the Parliament. The Parliament does not have untrammelled power because the Executive is the executive of the day. Likewise, recourse extends through the courts, the judiciary and each element within our constitutional structure, which has been developed over hundreds of years and which gives those checks and balances. I believe this provision is a further development of that basic constitutional thrust. It is one which the Australian Democrats support and one which we believe the Opposition should also support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I really do not need a sanctimonious lecture from Senator Macklin about the propriety of governments.
—It's about time you woke up to yourself.

—Senator Macklin knows nothing about the subject. He has just given us a quite unnecessary and offensive lecture. The fact is that he has revealed total double standards and those double standards are shared by the Government on this issue. The premise on which this whole seedy package of amendments is presented is that Ministers cannot be trusted. TALK.START.PARA: —The major amendment that the Opposition wished to make to this Australian Security Intelligence Organization Amendment Bill was to clause 5. We discussed that during the debate on the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Bill 1986, with the consent of honourable senators, and I will not now be moving that amendment. SPEECH.PARA: One of the interesting, and perhaps even disturbing, features of this amending legislation to the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act 1979 is the elimination of the notion of domestic subversion. Senator Harradine spoke on this matter yesterday during the second reading debate. I do not know whether he wishes to pursue it in Committee. I share the concern which he expressed in that contribution. It is a matter which has bothered me for some time. As I said in my speech during the second reading debate yesterday, over the years I have watched what I would describe as the paranoia of elements of the Australian Labor Party in relation to the traditional role of ASIO as set out in its current charter-it has been its role for a long time. Basically its role is to deal with matters of security which are defined as espionage, sabotage, subversion, active measures of foreign intervention and terrorism. `Subversion' is given an extended definition in the existing act which we have not yet altered, although we seem to be rapidly moving in that direction in the debate now.

I recall a very extensive debate in 1979 when the current Act was going through this chamber. As a matter of fact, I recall that that debate seemed to be almost as long as the debate we had on the Australian Bill of Rights Bill, but the statistics disprove that. It was certainly a very long debate. A good deal of time was spent on the proposed definitions. As I have said, I have been closely watching the development of views in the Labor Party about this matter. It is perfectly clear that a major aspect of its obsession with ASIO is its function of monitoring and reporting on subversive activities. The Australian Labor Party made a major submission to Mr Justice Hope in which it dealt at great length with this aspect. I think it influenced Mr Justice Hope to some extent in the recommendations he made. I think his views on the Inspector-General were also influenced by the strength of the ALP submission. It has resulted in the abandonment of the notion of subversion. It has been wiped out of the legislation and replaced by other definitions.

The Bill contains a new definition of acts of foreign interference, instead of the old definition of active measures of foreign intervention. There is a notion of attacks on Australia's defence system, and a very extended definition of politically motivated violence takes up the old notion of subversion. The definition of subversion in the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act meets very clearly the point about which Senator Harradine is concerned, namely that we may well have an organisation dedicated to the overthrow of our political system and the destruction of the constitutional system and government of the Commonwealth, which is not promoting violence as such but which has violence up its sleeve or in the closet, so to speak, to be used if necessary. Such an organisation, if its efforts at disinformation, clandestine activities, and so on do not succeed, may have violence in mind as the ultimate weapon.

That is a very serious matter for the community. It is an appropriate function of a security organisation to monitor what is going on in organisations of that kind. We have the authority now in the words of the present Director-General, whose recent speech to the National Press Club, from which I quoted in my speech in the second reading debate, completely exploded the theories about which Senator Harradine, the Opposition and I share a concern that these matters are just alarmist, old fashioned and unjustified and belong to another day and age. Mr Wrigley is a new man to the security field. He came in from outside and he confesses that he did not know much about it, but after 12 months as Director-General of ASIO he has made a major contribution. He has certainly indicated that these are matters of concern to our society. They are threats to our society and clearly should be watched. There is a good deal of confusion about the monitoring role of a security organisation such as ASIO as compared with its enforcement role. There may not be any justification at all for taking law enforcement action, criminal proceedings, or any other action against a group of people at their present stage of thinking. That may be completely unjustified. Nevertheless, if these organisations are a potential threat to our system and way of life, watching them is quite justified. It is quite appropriate for a security organisation, acting in a discreet way, which ASIO now does-and if it is able to do anything effective after this legislation goes through-to watch these organisations. In fact, that is necessary.

I am concerned, like Senator Harradine, that the new definition of `politically motivated violence' is not clear. The legislation does not make it clear. One can only assume from what has been said and from the elimination of the word `subversion' altogether that it is the intention of the Government that bodies of this kind, identified so clearly by Senator Harradine yesterday, should not be the subject of attention from ASIO. The mere fact that the word `violence' is used in the phrase `politically motivated violence' seems to suggest that that is the intention. However, when one looks at the fine print of the definition of `politically motivated violence', particularly limb (b) (ii), it seems that this legislation would enable ASIO to watch these organisations. It is left in doubt, and I fear that it is left in doubt for the Government's political reasons. The Government wants to be able to tell its left wing paranoiac elements that it is not going to allow ASIO to watch over their mates, or others. At the same time, it seems as though the definition has been couched in a way which will meet the concerns Senator Harradine and I have expressed. I would like the Government to come clean one way or another on it. It has abandoned the notion of subversion completely, with a big splash. It says: `We now have a better way of doing it, a more modern way. We want to be up to date'. The Government wants to have regard for civil liberties and human rights and all the things it is constantly mouthing. But is the government really dinkum about this-I hope that it is-or is it keeping a foot in the door? I want to get it clear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — My response was not a matter of contempt; it was just a matter of not wanting to tread over ground that has already been trodden or to bore anyone to death. The points I can make may well have been made already by the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes), who has been handling the Bill to this point. There is no intention, by the rewriting of the definitional provisions-in particular removing the concept of `subversion' as it previously existed-to reduce the effectiveness of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation to deal with threats, real and potential, of a kind that Senator Harradine at least was concerned about. Nor do we think there will be any such lessening of effectiveness.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important-I think this is the basic point-that ASIO use its resources efficiently and effectively for intelligence collection. This means devoting its investigative capacity to activities that represent a real threat to the security of the nation. It is very much in line with the recommendation of Mr Justice Hope that the Bill deletes the very vague term `subversion' from the definition of `security' in favour of the rather more precise concept of `politically motivated violence'. Essentially, the reason is to focus on the concept of a real threat rather than a threat which is three, four or five degrees away from reality or likely implementation. It is only those activities which can reasonably be regarded as being of genuine security concern within a contemporary time frame that will now attract the powers that the Organisation has. We believe that is perfectly appropriate.

I think the point ought to be made that there is no limitation on the Organisation's capacity to go on collecting material that in one way or another is on the public record and in that sense to keep an eye on developments right across the political and associated spectrums that may, in turn, over time, lead to concerns arising about the definitions in the legislation actually being attracted; in other words, the sorts of things Senator Harradine is concerned about, some very early nascent development of an organisation which may not have overtly articulated views or, more particularly, may not be engaging in actions that are likely to attract these definitional concerns at the moment.

It may nonetheless be an organisation or group of individuals which has a possibility of attracting that concern in the future. There is no reason why ASIO, in the course of its ordinary duties to gather information, cannot accumulate such material and be accordingly prepared to use such powers and investigative capacity as it has later should these definitions be attracted. It is very difficult to draw some of these lines, but the important point is to ensure that the organisation does not waste its resources, as many have suspected it has wasted them in the past-quite apart from the civil liberty implications-in engaging in the full panoply of investigative activities in relation to possible subversion under the old definition, which was wide enough to encompass behaviour many degrees away from anything that might reasonably be thought to properly attract the concern of the nation.

It is important to appreciate that there is no question in any of this measure that any activities which could possibly be regarded as constituting terrorism, or which are potentially involved in maybe leading to terrorism, will be excluded. The `politically motivated violence' definition, in the way in which it is constructed in the Bill, is clearly wide enough to encompass that, which in many ways is the central area of concern for any security organisation in this or any other country at present.

I think that is really all I can say in general terms. I am happy to offer, if that is any help to Senator Harradine, the general assurance that he seeks that we understand the point that he is making and do not see the language of this Bill as in any way undermining the effectiveness of this or any other government or security organisation to keep itself informed of developments which might in due course properly attract security concern.

TALK.START.PARA: — On behalf of the Government, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 12, clause 23, lines 14 to 16, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
Findings of Tribunal
`23. Section 60 of the Principal Act is amended-
(a) by omitting from sub-section (1) ``or as to the question to which the assessment relates''; and
(b) by inserting after sub-section (1) the following sub-section:

``(1a) The Tribunal shall not make findings in relation to an assessment that would, under section 61, have the effect of superseding any information that is, under sub-section 37 (2), deemed to be part of the assessment unless those findings state that, in the opinion of the Tribunal, the information is incorrect, incorrectly represented or could not reasonably be relevant to the requirements of security.''.'.

This amendment is an exercise in fine tuning rather than a substantive change. It relates to the Security Appeals Tribunal. The function of that Tribunal is to review adverse or qualified security assessments furnished to government agencies by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. An adverse assessment contains an opinion, advice or information which is or could be prejudicial to the interests of the person involved, together with a recommendation from ASIO that relevant action, such as the granting of a security clearance, be not taken. A qualified assessment contains an opinion, advice or information but does not contain a positive recommendation. The proposed amendment is to clarify the effect of the Tribunal's findings in respect of information contained in the statement of grounds upon which an adverse or qualified security assessment is based.

The amendment is to make it clear that information is to be deleted by the Tribunal from an assessment only if that information is incorrect, incorrectly represented or could not reasonably be relevant to the requirements of security. The amendment does not affect the Tribunal's power to include in its finding an opinion on the weight to be given to any particular information. The amendment also complements the new definition of `qualified security assessment' which is provided for in clause 19 (b) of the Bill. Accordingly, I commend the amendment to the Committee.

We are here dealing with a committee of the Parliament. Proposed new sub-section 92c (4) says clearly:
The functions of the Committee do not include-
(a) reviewing a matter that relates to the obtaining or communicating by the Organization of foreign intelligence;
(b) reviewing an aspect of the activities of the Organization that does not affect any person who is an Australian citizen or a permanent resident;
(c) reviewing a matter, including a matter that relates to intelligence collection methods or sources of information, that is operationally sensitive; or
(d) originating inquiries into individual complaints concerning the activities of the Organization.

The Australian Democrats, though we may quibble about some of those items, accept nevertheless that the functions of the committee should not include each of them. The debate is not about whether or not the committee should inquire into those matters. The question that we raise with our amendment is who is going to decide whether a matter falls under the provisions of sub-section (4). In particular, I draw the attention of the Minister to (4) (c) which, to paraphrase, excludes from the functions of the committee the reviewing of a matter that is operationally sensitive. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

Clause 11 (Definition of seditious intention).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 3, clause 11, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
`11. Section 24a of the Principal Act is amended-
(a) by adding at the end of paragraph (a) `or to excite disaffection against the Sovereign'; and
(b) by omitting paragraphs (b), (c) and (e).'.

This is a small but important amendment to clause 11. It makes important changes, although short ones, to section 24a of the Crimes Act. Indeed, a number of important amendments to the Crimes Act are made in this Part of the Bill which give effect to the recommendations of Mr Justice Hope. Generally, they incorporate important protections for people which are absent from the existing Act, namely, as to their intention when they are engaged in seditious enterprises or purposes. In section 24a there is the elimination of three specific matters which amount to seditious purpose. Section 24a reads:
An intention to effect any of the following purposes . . .
(b) to excite disaffection against the Sovereign or the Government or Constitution of the United Kingdom or against either House of the Parliament of the United Kingdom;
It is proposed that that be taken out of the Crimes Act. The section also says:
to excite disaffection against the Government or Constitution of any of the Queen's dominions.
(e) to excite disaffection against the connection of the Queen's dominions under the Crown.
Remaining as seditious purposes in section 24a after those amendments would be a purpose or intention:
to bring the Sovereign into hatred or contempt; to excite disaffection against the Government or Constitution of the Commonwealth or against either House of the Parliament of the Commonwealth-
that is, the Commonwealth of Australia-

to excite Her Majesty's subjects to attempt to procure the alteration, otherwise than by lawful means, of any matter in the Commonwealth established by law of the Commonwealth; or . . . to promote feelings of ill-will and hostility between different classes of Her Majesty's subjects so as to endanger the peace, order or good government of the Commonwealth.

These amendments leave the very important provisions as to seditious intention. When looking at the amendments that have been proposed, it is pretty clear that their intention is to remove from the definition of `seditious intention' intentions which relate to countries other than Australia but which historically have been treated as Australian interests because of their close association with the United Kingdom and the Commonwealth. So it is intended to take out of the definition of `seditious intention' the purpose of disaffection against the government or constitution of the United Kingdom or against either House of Parliament or disaffection against the constitution or government of any of the dominions, which now is a pretty old-fashioned expression, anyway. The other definition, which I do not need to read again, is in the same vein.

The amendment removes from the definition of `seditious intention' exciting disaffection against the sovereign. Some mistake has occurred. Utter confusion seems to have reigned in the House of Representatives. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), perhaps not surprisingly, did not seem to understand what it was all about. I am sure that even with my limited powers of advocacy I will be able to explain to Senator Evans what this is about. Whether he agrees is another matter. The point of the Opposition's amendment is that we should retain in the notion of seditious intention an intention to effect the purpose of exciting disaffection against the sovereign. Instead of having that stated separately we suggested that to the limb being preserved `to bring the Sovereign into hatred or contempt' the words in limb (b) `or to excite disaffection against the Sovereign' should be added. We have no problem with the rest of the section because there are very sensible and logical reasons for the elimination of the other elements. They all hang together, as I have explained.

We do not regard the sovereign as the sovereign of the United Kingdom or some other dominion. She is the sovereign of Australia. It is just as inappropriate for people to excite disaffection against her as it is to bring her into hatred and contempt, which part of the Act the Government intends to retain, or to excite disaffection against the Government or Constitution of the Commonwealth or either House of Parliament, which part also the Government intends to retain. We support that but something has gone wrong. We ought to retain exciting disaffection against the sovereign as a seditious intention. That is the purpose of our amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — I confess to a certain unease about retaining any of the language on the statute book. It all seems to me to be gloriously archaic to be making it possible still for people to be subject to impri-sonment for three years under the Crimes Act for engaging in a seditious enterprise if that seditious enterprise is defined, as it is in the Crimes Act in section 24b, as `an enterprise undertaken in order to carry out a seditious intention'. In the definition of `seditious intention' one finds that the sorts of things constitu-ting seditious intention include an intention to bring the sovereign into hatred or contempt or to excite disaffection in various ways against the Government or the Constitution.
—Or abolish the Senate.
—There is a sense in which all this language, if carried to its logical or perhaps illogical conclusion, could be quite a profound inhibitor of free, political, robust debate about institutions.
—You are going well beyond your brief.
—That may be so, but I have to be allowed some latitude.
—You can claim jet lag.

—I could always explain it as jet lag if the occasion demands, as Senator Macklin reminds me. It is important to appreciate the context in which we are debating this new refinement to the archaicism of it all which Senator Durack, with his customary enthusiasm in such matters, has put before us. At the outset, I am saying that it is wholly unlikely that any of this stuff will mean anything in practice. If it did turn out to mean something in practice it would be a fairly alarming state of affairs. Since it is in the statute book and there is an argument about it, I simply say that `to bring the sovereign into hatred or contempt', which the Government-I will not say in its wisdom-has agreed to retain in the statute book as a form of seditious intent which would justify a criminal prosecution, is certainly enough to include the phenomenon of exciting disaffection against the sovereign. As a result, there is no need to add that language to paragraph (a), as Senator Durack is proposing.

SPEECH.PARA: We are in no disagreement with the desirability of removing paragraphs (b), (c) and (e), which extend to exciting disaffection against other people's sovereigns or other countries. It is only a question as to whether the language of exciting disaffection against the sovereign should be added to the language of bringing the sovereign into hatred or contempt. It seems to me that if one is in the business of exciting disaffection one is clearly in the business of bringing the sovereign into hatred or contempt. I suggest that the amendment is unnecessary, quite apart from everything else that might be thought to be wrong with this provision. It would not be desirable to extend it any further that was strictly necessary to retain its core meaning. That is the position that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) took in the House of Representatives. Accordingly, it is the position that I express on behalf of the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Australian Democrats will not support the Opposition's amendment. Archaic or anachronistic as these items might be, I presume that in civilised times gone by some people managed to lose their heads over such activities. When wandering around the Tower of London the places where people lost their heads over having aroused at least a mild disaffection for the sovereign are gleefully pointed out. I could not put out of my mind the rather delightful story about the corgis that I saw being told by Gough Whitlam on the Clive James program. It seems to me that the corgis' particular activity in that story may very well have excited disaffection against the sovereign and come under the Crimes Act. I do not agree with the Minister that if one is exciting disaffection against the sovereign one is into hatred and contempt. It seems to me that the Crimes Act ought to cover only those serious matters, that people who wander around exciting disaffection against the sovereign are wholly excusable individuals within our society and that no crime or penalty ought to be attached to them, whether one agrees with them or not. I think that the paragraph about bringing the sovereign into hatred and contempt is important and ought to be retained, in as much as the Sovereign is the Head of State. In a constitutional monarchy it seems to me appropriate that that item should remain. I think that the other items are certainly from times gone by and it is useful when these opportunities arise to eliminate at least some of the rather odd bits that are still on the statute book.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I moved this amendment on the assumption that there had been a foul-up in the drafting of this proposal. I now find that the Government is really quite serious about it and is supported by the Democrats. This is a matter of great concern. It is a pity that when we come to discuss questions relating to loyalty to the Queen and the status of the Queen in our Constitution it becomes a matter of frivolity between members of the Labor Party and the Democrats. We know perfectly well where the Labor Party and Senator Gareth Evans stand. Senator Evans wants to abolish the flag, and no doubt he wants in due course to abolish the office of Queen as Queen of Australia and then set up a presidency, for which he will no doubt be a candidate. But this a serious matter. I am surprised that the Government has seriously proceeded with this proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: The arguments that Senator Gareth Evans has advanced simply do not hold water. The Government and Senator Macklin want to get rid of old notions about exciting disaffection. I know these are old-fashioned phrases. They have been around for a long time, but they have legal meaning and they have been applied. Maybe they could be better expressed. But neither the Government nor Senator Macklin is taking exception to or suggesting any amendment to all the other provisions of the Crimes Act which use the phrase `disaffection against the Government or Constitution of the Commonwealth or either House of the Parliament of the Commonwealth'. We are leaving in there what the Government and the Democrats think is a rather foolish old phrase or a matter of joke. We are leaving in there that phrase as it relates to ourselves; that is, it remains a seditious intention `to excite disaffection against the Government or Constitution of the Commonwealth or either House of the Parliament of the Commonwealth' and an enterprise undertaken in pursuance of such an intention remains a seditious enterprise.

For goodness sake, let us have some logic in this proposal. Senator Evans apparently is serious about getting rid of these notions. It is not his brief-it is not the Government's proposal-to do so, but at least it is more logical than the Government's proposal, which is to retain these notions in relation to ourselves, to the Government and so on, but to take them out in relation to the sovereign. Exciting disaffection against the sovereign is not the same as bringing the sovereign into hatred or contempt. That is a different notion. It is not good enough to say, as Senator Evans has said: `Well, we don't need that there because we are retaining the seditious intention of bringing the sovereign into hatred or contempt'.

The point is that, after the other amendments are passed, it will not be an offence carrying a penalty of imprisonment for three years simply to engage in an enterprise to give effect to this intention. Very properly-I think this is what Mr Justice Hope was basically concerned about in the sections which create the offences and which invoke the penalty of three years imprisonment-as the amendment to section 24c provides, it is an offence only if it is done `with the intention of causing violence or creating public disorder or a public disturbance'. These intentions are added in other sections.

They are the ways in which the Government proposes to go to eliminate the criticism of this whole section that Senator Evans has expressed. They limit very considerably what are probably the too wide definitions that appear in the offence-creating clause of the Crimes Act, and the Opposition is not in any way objecting to that. What we are objecting to is this further attempt to place the sovereign on a lower rung, so to speak, than the rest of the Constitution, which includes the Government and ourselves as members of one of the Houses of Parliament. I think it is appropriate to retain the original notion. It may be better to have it in more modern language-I concede that-but the Government is not proposing that. It is retaining the term `disaffection' in relation to other parts of the Constitution. I find it extraordinary that the Government wants to eliminate that notion from the role of the sovereign.

This whole thing seems to have acquired a great deal more significance than I thought it would. When I saw this amendment I felt it was simply a mistake and therefore moved my amendment. I had every reason to believe that from the debate in the House of Representatives. It now turns out that it is not a mistake, that it is the clear intention of the Government to treat the sovereign in a different way from the way in which it treats the rest of the Constitution, and I certainly will press the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been listening carefully to what Senator Durack, Senator Gareth Evans and Senator Macklin have said. I understand what Senator Durack was getting at, but in the absence of anything coming from the Government which would persuade me to vote for the Opposition's amendment, there must be some reason that is being put forward by the Government for its amendment. I offer this consideration to the Committee: It seems to me that it is not an appropriate argument to say that because the provision relating to excitement to disaffection against the Senate or both Houses of Parliament is to be retained it should therefore be retained for the sovereign. The sovereign is both an institution and a person. The Senate is not a person, it is an institution. Although persons can incite others to hatred or contempt for the Senate, nevertheless that is not a direct thrust against a person-it is against an institution-and thus the wording `excitement to disaffection' is probably more appropriate in the legal sense towards an institution than it is towards a person. As the Head of State the sovereign embodies the principles upon which that society is established.

SPEECH.PARA: There may well be people who would seek to excite disaffection from the sovereign as an institution. To do that, one would assume they would be inciting persons to hatred and contempt of that institution and may, in the course of that action, be reflecting on the Queen as a person. Therefore, it seems to me that the provision that will be retained, the provision about exciting hatred and contempt for the sovereign, covers the question of exciting disaffection for the sovereign. Under those circumstances I will not be supporting the Opposition's amendment. I am not clear on what the legal definition of disaffection is. I have hurriedly tried to get that definition but I do not have it at present.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to Senator Harradine for offering one possible way through this and the distinction between institutions and individuals and so on. I am rather inclined to accept the logic of Senator Durack's view that if we are to retain a provision which in effect prohibits the exciting of disaffection against the Government and the Constitution, we have to come up with some reason for not having a similar provision as far as the sovereign is concerned. Rather than resolving the inconsistency-if indeed there is one-in favour of adding a reference to exciting disaffection against the sovereign, my personal preference would be to remove the reference to exciting disaffection against the Parliament and the Constitution. I undertake to the Committee to raise this with the Government. It is far beyond my brief at the moment and I do not want to urge the Australian Democrats to move an amendment because we could not support it at this stage. I think concerns from the point of view of free speech and so on have emerged in this debate about the retention of paragraph (d). There might be some justification for its existence which I cannot think of at the moment. In looking at it by itself, it seems to raise real problems of principle in a way that is not true, for example, of paragraphs (f) and (g) which are not unimportant provisions to retain, or in fact paragraph (a)-bringing the sovereign into hatred or contempt-if that is what is intended. It is not just the intention to do it but the success in bringing the sovereign into hatred and contempt that would have the capacity to undermine that institution. In the same way, the mere exciting or attempting to excite disaffection against the Constitution or the Government is not regarded, I think, appropriately as something which is dangerous but rather as something that is part of the cut and thrust of ordinary democracy as we know it.

SPEECH.PARA: That being said, what do we do with paragraph (a) at the moment? I think we should leave it exactly as it is on the basis that it does what it has to do to protect the institution. I think anything added to it is redundant. If we were to add the concept of exciting disaffection against the sovereign we would have a situation of the exciting of disaffection being of such an order of seriousness that it results in the sovereign being brought into hatred or contempt, in which case the problem would be covered by the existing language of paragraph (a); or, alternatively, an exciting of disaffection which was not so serious as to succeed in bringing the sovereign into hatred or contempt but was merely a bit of stirring by the individual organisation in question, which seems to me not to be the sort of thing which ought to be prohibited by law.

As Senator Durack reminds us, the remaining part of section 24c of the Crimes Act will in fact be amended to require not just a seditious intention in the abstract but an intention of actually causing violence or creating public disorder or public disturbance. Even with the insertion of that further proviso, the intention of creating a public disorder or violence is not the same as achieving disorder or violence. So it is still possible for someone to be prosecuted and gaoled for three years for saying something which might be thought as exciting disaffection, saying it with the intention of generating a degree of disorder, but succeeding in doing nothing of the kind, and nobody taking any notice of it at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Attempts are criminal.
—But attempts, maybe, ought not to be criminal when--
—What about attempts at murder?

—There is a hell of a difference, as I thought even Senator Du-rack would understand, between murdering someone and speaking out against the inequity of either the Constitution and the Parliament or-goodness gracious-the sovereign. TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that, prior to this debate coming on, the Government indicated its intention to support Senator Harradine's amendment. The Opposition has also changed its view and intends to support Senator Harradine's amendment. That will transpire shortly. That being the case, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed new sub-clause 4a (1), leave out paragraph (a) to (e) (inclusive), insert:
`by omitting paragraph 7.1, and substituting the following paragraph:

a parent;
a son or daughter other than a dependent child as defined in paragraph 1.19;
a brother or sister; or

of the Senator or member.''.'.

It seems to me that the item on which people have focused, that is, the notion of de factos travelling overseas with members and senators, is the issue on which Senator Harradine's amendment is being supported. I have moved my amendment to seek to avoid the continuing discrimination against a range of other people. I emphasise again, for the sake of the Press and those people who may read this part of the debate, that we are talking about travel outside Australia. We are talking about a procedure whereby the first class air fare which is provided every three years to a member or senator is able to be downgraded at no cost to the revenue to enable a spouse to travel overseas with that member or senator. In other words, we are not talking about adding costs to the revenue; we are talking about the distribution of costs which are already there. So it is not a matter of costs. Quite frankly, it becomes a debate about de facto spouses.

The Government seemingly will make clear that it will support Senator Harradine's amendment, as the Opposition is now supporting it. On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I seek to try to pick up a range of other people who will be discriminated against because of this move by the Government and the Opposition. Those people include senators and members who are widows and widowers, people who have their grown-up children performing a whole range of functions that those of us who have spouses ask our spouses to perform. I refer to the incessant answering of phones, attending public meetings, dragging them, willing or otherwise, to fetes, and the 101 other things they do in support of our public lives, let alone our private lives. Particularly members and senators who are widows and widowers often have their grown-up children performing those tasks for them. I think it is outrageous that we cannot downgrade air fares to compensate those people in some way, in the same way as we are able to downgrade air fares to compensate spouses. After all, that is what we are talking about.

There are situations where members and senators have spouses in which I think it would also be appropriate, for example, in the case of a spouse who is disabled and unable to travel and where a relative, a daughter or a son, performs those types of duties that a spouse would normally perform. Again it seems to me to be utterly outrageous and an added imposition on those senators and members who have disabled spouses that they should be further disadvantaged by this procedure, which is being entered into in a shabby operation by the Government, in collusion with the Opposition. In those circumstances it seems to me that the eldest child, a brother or a sister, or in many cases a parent, who performs that range of public duties, ought to be able to undertake that travel.

We left the following item out of our amendment because we did not think we could get Government or Opposition support. I hope the Government and the Opposition will support the proposal I have moved. I raised the matter of staff on a previous occasion, as I raised the other matter on a previous occasion. Talking frankly, the reason people say they do not want staff included in the travel provision is the notion that a senator or member may be having sexual intercourse with a member of that parliamenta-rian's staff. That is the reason we are looking at the exclusion of a provision for staff; let us have it frankly on the record. The point I want to make about this exercise is that it may very well be much more appropriate, in the public good, for a parliamentarian to take a member of staff than to take his or her spouse on an overseas trip.

As a personal example, I went overseas a couple of years ago. A member of my staff paid privately to accompany me. That member of staff performed duties admirably. In the eight days I was overseas I was able to do far more because the member of staff was there to make arrangements, to do follow-up work, to get material and do a whole host of other things. Ha-ving that staff member with me probably quadrupled the amount of work I was able to do on that trip. Of course, that is the reason why Prime Ministers and Ministers on occasions take staff overseas-to assist them in the duties they are asked to perform on behalf of the community. We have reached an absurd situation because of an obsession with the private life of members of parliament. We are probably cutting off our nose to spite our face by engaging in an activity which will possibly make our task less efficient and less beneficial for the community.

I return to the points that I raised with regard to this matter. It seems reasonable that the people detailed under the definition of `nominee' ought to be acceptable to the Government and to the Opposition. The Opposition has again changed its mind although, quite rightly, it previously moved such an amendment. Never knowing what it is that it believes in, it has now changed its mind and will vote for the very amendment it opposed last time the issue arose. It may assist the Opposition if I read a letter from Women Who Want to be Women. The letter is written to Senator Haines and reads:
Dear Madam,
We request you support Senator Harradine's amendment to the Remuneration and Allowances Alteration Bill 1986.
Senator Harradine undoubtedly would agree that the letter starts off well. It continues:

Whilst we agree any parliamentarian should be entitled to take their spouse, parent, sibling, children or any bona fide employee overseas, we object to MPs taking their de facto or mistress at the taxpayers expense.

Women Who Want to be Women get down to the nitty-gritty-it is who is having sexual intercourse with whom that it is interested in and that is all. That is what we are talking about. The letter continues:
Furthermore, we believe all MPs should set an example to all Australian citizens in upholding traditional attitudes towards marriage and the family.
Senator Haines, in response, said:
Thank you for your recent letter regarding the Remuneration and Allowances Alteration Bill 1986.
Most parliamentarians agree with you-
when the vote is taken we will see whether most parliamentarians agree-

that they ``should be allowed to take their spouse, parent, sibling children or any bona fide employee overseas''. Unfortunately, the effect of Senator Harradine's amendment was to preclude a parliamentarian from taking-
such people-

. . . overseas. The amendment passed by the Senate to change the Government's legislation from ``spouse or de facto'' to ``spouse or nominee'', however, would have covered the people that you mentioned.

I believe that the amendment moved by Senator Harradine to which I have moved an amendment discriminates against parliamentarians who are widows or widowers and parliamentarians who have a disabled spouse. It is not appropriate that that should be allowed to occur. In many circumstances the spouses of parliamentarians may have other bona fide reasons why they are unable to accompany their spouses. It may be that they are a member of parliament or engaged in a reserve occupation such as in the armed forces. In other words, we are seeking to set up a whole range of discriminations by the action on which the Government and the Opposition are about to embark.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you raised it with the Tribunal?

—Senator Harradine has moved an amendment to alter the operation of the Tribunal. We should not discriminate against the people I mentioned. The amendment I have circulated would allow this. I intend to put my amendment to the vote. I hope that honourable senators will not pursue continuing discrimination against widows, widowers, children and people who are disadvantaged because of their public duty. We should not embark on the odd exercise proposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I am glad you are in the chair and not I in the light of that explanation. My views on this matter I think are well known. Senator Harradine, for all the reasons that he has expressed in the past, wishes to remove from the entitlement of a parliamentarian the right to be accompanied overseas by a de facto spouse, as it is known, or `somebody who has established a bona fide domestic relationship', to use the words of the Remuneration Tribunal. I see no reason why we as parliamentarians should consider respectable a long-standing marriage in which one spouse or other physically or psychologically abuses the other and yet ignore a long-standing loving, respecting relationship which, for reasons that the people are involved in, has not been sanctified in a church or made orderly in a registry office or by a marriage celebrant, but I will not go into that further.

SPEECH.PARA: What Senator Macklin wants now to do, I think under the guise of being anti-discriminatory, is to include in the overseas travel conditions for parliamentarians their being allowed to be accompanied by parents, sons or daughters other than dependent children, brothers or sisters and other close relatives, as is allowed for domestic travel. By adding his amendment to Senator Harradine's amendment I assume he also wants to discriminate against the de facto. Apparently nobody in this place except me is prepared to get up to defend the poor old de facto spouse or disabled spouse.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are voting against it.
—Wait a minute; just hold on. We have a situation here where the Government, in difficult economic circumstances-

—It is not costing any more.

—Hang on; good Senator, do not be so impatient. The Special Minister of State (Mr Young) informs me that, in fact, it would extend the cost; that parliamentarians at the moment who are widowed, single, et cetera, frequently change their nominee from one parent to another or to sons, daughters, brothers, sisters and other close relatives, and that they will do this for overseas travel. Whereas most parliamentarians do not take up their full overseas travel entitlements, it is anticipated that under these circumstances they would, which would therefore increase the cost to the exchequer. That is the Government's view and that is why the Government is opposing this.
—Because you can take your mother, you are going to go overseas now; is that right?

—No; it is because if one can take one's mother, daughter or son overseas, one is likely to do so. That is exactly what it is about. I find the letter from Women Who Want to be Women typical of their approach. They are perfectly happy for us to take--

—They are not very helpful to Senator Harradine. They are perfectly happy for a member of parliament to take overseas his wife whom he belts every Friday night when he goes home full. But they will not let him take someone with whom he has been living in a bona fide stable, loving, domestic relationship for years. At least Senator Harradine is honest. —You do too.
—No, I do not.
—You know that is not true.
—No, that is true. That is exactly what it is about. We have a situation in which we have all been getting $400 a month extra-

—If Senator Harradine wants to scrap the whole Bill, I will certainly do that. I can certainly guarantee that I will get support from this side of the chamber. I would be the first to concede that what we are doing here by not opposing Senator Harradine's amendment is intruding into the bedrooms of members of parliament in a way that we would not be willing to intrude on our electors, but I have to get this legislation through. The practicality of it is that Senator Harradine may think he has had a triumph, but I think people will find ways of getting over that triumph in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to speak at length, but Senator Macklin has accused me of discriminating against some people and Senator Grimes has accused me of making moral judgments. Let me just say what the effect of the proposal is. We are talking about section 7 (1) of the Remuneration Tribunal's 1986 review. TALK.START.PARA: —Fair go!
—Be serious. The provision says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . `nominee' means a person with whom the senator or member has established a bona fide-
I wonder who is going to decide that-
stable-
somebody has to make a judgment about that-
domestic relationship.

All I say is that we should just stick to the legally married; we need not make a judgment about whether or not they are happily married. One does not have to make that judgment. One just simply sticks to the law. Who is being judgmental? I am certainly not being judgmental. I am simply stating that pursuant to the law, for example, an authorised marriage celebrant must give to persons intending marriage a document which says that Parliament places great stress on the importance of marriage and the family-and so we do. We should bear in mind that the Tribunal's action, the Government having placed a submission before it, publicly demeans the institution of marriage. It strikes at the legislative recognition of marriage and flies in the face of the responsibility of parliamentarians to uphold the principles underpinning the laws that they pass through Parliament. All my provision does is correct that. As far as Senator Macklin's proposition is concerned, I am not discriminating against anybody. Those persons mentioned in his amendment do not at present have any entitlement at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —They would have under the nominee scheme.
—I know they would, but the point is--

—I just point out to the honourable senator that the reason the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) gave the last time he rejected that amendment was that it would establish a most undesirable precedent for the Parliament to override a determination of the independent Tribunal.

SPEECH.PARA: We have set up the Remuneration Tribunal and the Democrats are proposing that this matter not be submitted to it. If they want to go to the Tribunal with that submission, that is fair enough. It is then up to us to overturn the Tribunal's determination. If the Democrats wish to pursue what they are trying to pursue here, let them do so through the correct channels. The determination for this financial year is being considered. Let them make a submission along the lines they have outlined and let us do what we want to do with it when the Tribunal has made a determination.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposition which Senator Harradine puts is not acceptable. The only people who would be able to take advantage of our amendment if it were successful happen to be in the other political parties.

SPEECH.PARA: I reiterate the point that I have already made. Now that this whole operation has been opened up it seems that we are about to commit a further, quite deliberate, discrimination because we have the opportunity of doing otherwise. I would like to respond to one point the Minister put forward-I do not think he believed it-on behalf of the Government about costs. The liability of the Government would not be increased-whether the actual expenditure is increased is a matter of conjecture-if this proposed amendment were passed. It cannot be increased. I hope that in the whole of the debate somebody in the media will finally get that message. We are not talking about carting all and sundry overseas at added expense to the taxpayers in terms of their liability.

A member can proceed overseas only on study leave. In other words he can proceed overseas only if he is undertaking study for his constituency or his political work. It is unlikely-and indeed I would have thought it a disgraceful proposition for the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) to put-that members and senators would jaunt overseas. TALK.START.PARA: —He will go through yours next time.

—He has already approved them-and whether the spouse of the member is travelling with him is not relevant to those plans. In fact it is entirely irrelevant to those plans, as the Minister well knows. SPEECH.PARA: I think the arguments put forward are specious. However, I accept the Minister's last argument that he has to get the Bill passed. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macklin's oratory has not convinced me. I will refer to the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) Senator Macklin's concern about the apparent attitude of the Special Minister of State, who may be interpreted as suggesting that some parliamentarians go overseas and jaunt. I find it extraordinary that he said that he is not making a moral judgment; he is stopping us from making a moral judgment because people have to judge what is a bona fide domestic relationship. Apparently he is perfectly happy about making a moral judgment in those areas but he is not happy about making it in relation to the poor old parliamentarians.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know what the Australian Democrats have against sex. They seem to have a real problem because apparently it is all right, according to their amendment, to take people overseas if they are one's parents, sons or daughters, brothers or sisters or close relatives, but if they cohabit-to use the vernacular-and therefore are apparently indulging in that sort of behaviour they will be excluded. I think that is a bit unfair; it is discriminating against such people. This is a reflection of the sort of nonsense that goes on here sometimes, and I am the first to admit that it is nonsense. We are making a judgment that the whole of Australia shares Senator Harradine's views about human behaviour. The reason the Government is not opposing his amendment is the reason I gave earlier-we have to get the legislation passed.

I hope that between now and the next time this matter comes up people will get together and accept that it is 1986, that people's relationships differ and that people's views on things differ. Senator Harradine is winning this time not because he has the numbers but because of the special circumstances and because politicians in this country, unfortunately, are influenced more by colourful and spectacular headlines and the sorts of letters they get from Women Who Want to be Women than facts and good sense.

TALK.START.PARA: —I attempt to be a logical, rational human being. Some may take exception to this remark but I attempt to achieve these aims.
