TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I regret to inform the Senate that Senator Button and Senator Gietzelt will both be absent from the chamber during Question Time today. Any questions normally directed to either of those honourable senators should be directed to me.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy, who I know lately has been in happier places than Australia for any Minister in the Hawke Government. Is he aware that the Australian Mining Industry Council has revised its estimate of the cost to miners of the fringe benefits tax and upgraded it to $70m? Is the Minister aware also that the great bulk, if not the whole, of this amount is calculated from concessions offered to attract people to remote areas, and certainly not from the Prime Minister's favourite example of rorts and ramps in the city offices of mining companies? Was this huge increased impost on the mining industry an intended or unintended consequence of the fringe benefits tax? What steps will the Minister take to ensure that the impact on this industry will be fully taken into account in the review of that tax, which has now been announced by the Prime Minister?

—I am aware of AMIC's latest representations on this matter. In fact I saw a delegation from AMIC the day before I left for overseas a fortnight ago, from which that material was conveyed to me. The Government has, I know, over that period been examining the AMIC figures to see to what extent they do stand up to close scrutiny. The claim is, as Senator Durack indicated, that the cost of the fringe benefits tax for remote areas will be of the order of $70m in relation to the housing aspect and the vacation air fares, together with some lesser matters such as air-conditioning and so on. If the figure is indeed $70m, I suppose that would, as to magnitude anyway, rank as an unintended consequence. But it very much remains to be seen whether the figures will come out as they are claimed to be by the mining industry. If after closer analysis they do come out that way, that is something that the Government would, I hope, be looking at as part of the indicated administrative revision or review of the fringe benefits tax.

—I thank the Minister for that answer, but I wish to ask him a supplementary question. Does his answer mean that there is another review which in fact was initiated by the Government prior to the announcement made by the Prime Minister the other day, or is this going to be part of the review of the whole of the unintended consequences, so-called, which was announced this week while he was away?

—No earlier review has been set in train. It is simply a matter of the Government responding sensitively and intelligently, as it always does, to representations that are made to it by the interest groups that we serve. If claims are made and put forward in seriousness by a body as distinguished as the Australian Mining Industry Council, of course the Government will take those claims seriously and scrutinise them very minutely.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry whether his attention has been drawn to an article in the Weekend Australian quoting the Treasurer of the Liberal Party, Mr John Elliott, as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: When the next conservative government gets in I can tell you that the dollar is going to jump but we are probably not going to win an election by saying that.

What effect would a jump in the value of the dollar have on primary industry in this country? Having regard to the New Right industrial relations policies of the Opposition, is the jumping dollar scenario plausible?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to the last part of the question, I think the inference which can be drawn from Senator Cook's question is, quite correctly, that the industrial relations policy which the ratbag Right is foisting on the Liberal Party is a policy which will lead to massive industrial disputation and a dollar which is more likely to fall than to rise.

ANSWER.PARA: For the purposes of my answer to the first part of the question I will take at face value and accept as correct Mr Elliott's statement that the dollar is going to jump under the next conservative government. I have been asked what the effect of that would be on primary industry. For every percentage increase in the exchange rate farmers' returns would be reduced by about $100m. Therefore, if the exchange rate moved from its present level of $US0.63, or thereabouts, to just over $US0.70, say, farmers' returns would fall by $700m. That, of course, comes straight off net income as well as gross income, so farmers' net incomes would be reduced by some $700m. If Mr Elliott is asserting that the exchange rate, relative to the United States dollar, would return to the level it was at 18 or 20 months ago, it would rise about 30 per cent, which would be just over 20 points as against the United States dollar. That would wipe $2 billion off both gross and net farm income. The consequences of that, of course, would be catastrophic, particularly if that were superimposed on the present depressed price period through which agriculture is moving.

If a future coalition government were to take the same measures that a previous coalition government took-that is, maintain by a series of artificial devices an overvalued Australian dollar as a substitute for an effective wages policy-the exchange rate might well appreciate. The effects of that sort of policy, of course, would be not only to cause enormous damage to the agricultural sector but also to erode further the international competitiveness of the Australian manufacturing sector. In other words, there would be a rerun of the damage inflicted on the economy in the late 1970s and early 1980s by John Howard, as Treasurer, through maintaining quite deliberately, with artificial support, an overvalued exchange rate as a substitute for an effective wages policy. No matter what mechanism the Liberal Party believes that it would use to force the exchange rate up, I am sure that the people who mistakenly vote for a National Party politician ought to be absolutely terrified at the prospect of that Party getting back into a coalition government with the Liberals led by Mr Howard and directed by Mr Hay, Mr Elliott and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Treasurer advise the Senate of the approximate total cost of producing and direct mailing nearly half a million booklets entitled `Fringe Benefits Tax-A Guide for Employers' to employers across the country? In view of the Government's decision to review the scope of the fringe benefits tax, does the Minister agree that the booklets are now of limited use and the funds spent in compiling and mailing them have been largely wasted? Is the Government examining a proposal to spend $2m on an advertising campaign to promote and explain the fringe benefits tax? Will the Minister ensure that no decision is taken to waste more public money on such a dubious campaign, primarily designed to reduce the potential damage caused by the tax before the final form of the tax is decided on?

—Senator Messner referred to an alleged decision to reduce the scope of the tax. I think they were the words he used. I am not sure that I could endorse that as being an accurate statement, but I will let that pass. I cannot remember-although I think it came out in the Estimates committees hearing-the cost of mailing the half million booklets. Again I cannot remember off the top of my head the amount of money, but there is an appropriation-whether it is specifically identified as an appropriation I am not sure-for public information on the tax reform package. I will get the details of that from the Treasurer.

—I ask a supplementary question. The point I am trying to draw to the Minister's attention is the fact that the tax is now subject to review. Consequently, any public information campaign must be of dubious value until the final form of the tax is decided. Is the Government doing anything to hold up the public information campaign until that occurs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In that very short period- which is now just over a fortnight-before the modifications, if any, are decided upon and announced, I take it for granted that no material will be mailed out. In a bit over two weeks time the Government's decisions will be known. Everybody who is interested will then be told, either informally through the media or formally by the Australian Taxation Office through the distribution of the material. On the other hand, we will have to wait 18 months to find out what the Opposition is going to do about the termination of the practice Mr Hunt had the honesty to remember-tax evasion.

ANSWER.PARA: Various people, of course, in unguarded moments and in outbreaks of honesty, have been telling us that the Opposition will enforce section 26 (e) of the Income Tax Assessment Act. The Government's judgment is that section 26 (e) is not enforceable. If the Opposition really attempts to enforce it, several things will happen. First, the work load thrust upon employers will be vastly greater than the fringe benefits tax work load thrust upon the employers. Secondly, if the Opposition believes that section 26 (e) is enforceable it should go back over many years and make taxpayers pay the tax which has been evaded. I use that word in its legalistic sense because any income not declared, if the Opposition believes 26 (e) can be enforced, represents tax evasion-not tax avoidance, but evasion. If the Opposition is going to activate 26 (e)-and Senator Messner believes that it can be enforced-it will be legally and morally obliged to go back many years and collect that money years after the tax was evaded. No wonder the Opposition refuses to tell the public what it is going to do, because to have any credibility at all that is what it has to do. That is why it does not have the courage to tell the public for the next 12 or 18 months, or however long it will be, just what it is going to do. It is very wise, of course, in not coming clean with the public and telling the public what it intends to do, because the public will be horrified when it finds out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Resources and energy aware that the price of petrol in Tasmania is 10c to 15c more per litre than in the mainland States? Has the Minister seen the assertion of the Premier, Mr Gray, that the relatively high cost of petrol in Tasmania is due to the Federal tax on petrol as well as a lack of competition? Given that Tasmanians pay the highest State tax in Australia for their petrol, is it not this State tax which accounts for Tasmania's comparatively exorbitant petrol prices? Is there any accuracy in Mr Gray's claim that the Commonwealth is responsible?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen a Press report of the assertions of the Tasmanian Premier. As so often is the case, they are grossly misleading. It is simply not correct to say that the high price of petrol in Australia is a product of Federal taxation. Let me explain why. For a start, the Premier's figures are totally in error. It is simply not correct to say that the Commonwealth taxes on petrol total 33c per litre. The Commonwealth excise-that is the product excise-on petrol is currently 20.185c per litre and is about to fall to 19.7c per litre. Even if one is to take account, in addition to the product excise, of the Commonwealth's excise on crude oil produced here in Australia, which translates approximately to 7c per litre, the total Commonwealth tax on petrol is only 27c per litre, not 33c per litre as was claimed.

ANSWER.PARA: The primary cause for the difference between the situations in Tasmania and elsewhere is the actions which have been taken by the Tasmanian Government itself. On 1 August the Tasmanian Government increased the State franchise fee on petrol by almost 140 per cent, from 3.15c per litre to 7.52c per litre. This is the highest State tax on petrol. It is the highest tax which exists anywhere in the country. In New South Wales it is 3.53c, in Victoria it is 3.98c, in Western Australia it is 4.52c, in South Australia it is 2.51c, and in Tasmania it is 7.52c.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is it in Queensland?

—In Queensland it is zero, because of the total irresponsibility with which the Queensland Government has been using other forms of tax revenue in order to win cheap, crude and vulgar political popularity, including in particular, of course, the rail charges that it imposes on the mining industry to the great detriment of the mining industry in that State and of the national interest as a whole. As for Tasmania, it is supremely obvious that we have a government there which is taxing its constituents into the ground as far as petrol is concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: The further point I make regarding the differential in retail prices is that the Prices Surveillance Authority's current maximum endorsed wholesale price, which excludes State franchise fees, for Hobart is actually slightly below the maximum wholesale endorsed price for Sydney and Melbourne. So it is the inclusion of the State Government franchise fee which obviously causes that petrol price difference at the wholesale level. It has to be said that, attributable to the wholesale price differential, there is a further difference between Tasmanian and mainland prices compounded by the existence of discounting on the mainland, or at least in situations of major metropolitan aggregation where there are high volume outlets and especially, further, where that occurs near sources of bulk supplies such as refineries. There are, of course, no refineries in Tasmania, so that is a further reason, but the basic one, I repeat, as Senator Coates so clearly pointed out, is the effect of State imposts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Health seen the report in today's Australian indicating that various bureaucrats in various government departments will have access to the proposed National Births, Deaths and Marriages Register, thereby giving them access to such intimate personal details about individuals as information regarding adoption, legitimation and acknowledgment of paternity? Can the Minister confirm that this sort of information about people will be made available to such officers as senior members of the departments responsible for foreign affairs, taxation and social security as well as the Australian Statistician and the General Manager of the Health Insurance Commission? In view of the potential for gross invasion of privacy inherent in this proposal, will the Minister assure the Senate that privacy legislation to protect against possible infringements will be introduced at the same time as the legislation relating to the Australia Card is introduced and that it will operate irrespective of the fate of the Australia Card?

—I am sorry; I did not see the report in the Australian this morning. Therefore, I do not know any details about it, nor have I been briefed on the matter. I will refer the matters raised by Senator Haines to the Minister for Health. It is my understanding that the privacy legislation will be introduced at the same time. As for the other details, I will have to obtain them from the Minister I represent.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Resources and Energy. In the light of the decision by Peko-Wallsend Ltd to begin uranium exploration in Kakadu National Park, and noting the recent uncertainty surrounding the survival of the park, will the Minister give some assurance to the people of Australia and the Aboriginal communities in the area that their interests will be protected?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a little puzzled by Senator Childs's reference to recent uncertainty surrounding the survival of Kakadu National Park because this Government has made it absolutely and unequivocally clear that it is committed not only to the survival of the park but also to the maintenance of its integrity, as is appropriate given its status as not only one of Australia's but one of the world's great environmental treasures. I am very happy to give an assurance, which I think the Prime Minister will be in the process of giving about now in the other House, that there will be no mining of any sort in the areas comprising stages 1 and 2 of Kakadu National Park under the Hawke Labor Government. That is something we made perfectly clear in the joint statement of Mr Cohen and me some weeks ago. It is something I now make absolutely clear again on behalf of this Government.

ANSWER.PARA: So far as the report of Geopeko's exploration activities are concerned, the situation is this: Under the national parks legislation it is the case that pre-existing mineral interests are preserved. So Geopeko is entitled as a matter of law to explore in the area of its existing leases. If, as media reports indicate, Geopeko is exploring outside the area of its pre-existing mineral leases and simply in areas where it has lodged applications of one kind or another, the Government will seek to prevent that activity through the courts. As the Peko company has been advised on previous occasions, the Government does not accept that the mere application for a leasehold interest carries in itself any right to explore or to mine.

To come back to the existing leases for the sake of clarifying the situation, while the Government cannot prevent further exploration occurring on those existing leases, it will take every step within its power to ensure that no mining of any kind takes place within the existing Kakadu National Park. Peko-Wallsend has 14 mineral leases in the stage 2 area totalling around 550 acres, but in five separate areas. My information is that these leases, small and scattered as they are, simply do not provide a sufficient area to establish a mine, even if high grade ore should be located. The Commonwealth Government simply will not grant any additional leasehold interest such as to create an area of viability for mining purposes. I make the further point that, given that the existing leases are located not only in an area of obviously great natural beauty but also principally in sensitive wetlands subject to seasonal flooding, it is almost inconceivable that any proposal for mining activity could be consistent with the stringent environmental standards that the Australian Government is obliged to apply to World Heritage List areas, as these areas are.

So there should be no misunderstanding whatsoever on the part of the mining company, or anybody else, as it embarks on new exploration. The Government simply will not countenance any mining activity in the existing Kakadu National Park.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Given that there is currently a limit on the number of merino rams allowed to be exported, would the Minister outline the Government's views of the meatworkers union's intention to export merino rams and merino semen as a commercial operation, despite such enterprises not being in the long term interests of the Australian wool industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The assertion that the export of merino rams would not be in the interests of the Australian wool industry presumably is backed by no evidence. The critical factor in determining the correctness of that assertion is whether the Australian merino has any genetic superiority over merinos from other countries. Nobody knows whether or not that is true. If honourable senators were more interested in the subject, I could talk at some length about it. I could go back to a bit of history in the late 1960s and early 1970s when the coalition Government was in office and backed one of the shonkiest propaganda campaigns that has ever been devised by a government. The Government of that time made the same assertion as Senator Watson has made, which is that Australian merinos have genetic superiority over merinos in other countries and that, therefore, the availability of Australian merinos would increase the world supply of fine merino wool. That may or may not have been true, nobody actually knows. The shonky conclusion made was that because of the increase in the supply of wool, the price of wool would rise. Just in case anybody thinks that I am confused, it was asserted by the Australian Wool Board and endorsed by the red-necked government of the day that an increase in the supply of merino wool would cause the price of wool to rise.

ANSWER.PARA: As to an alleged scheme of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union, which I suppose is the union to which Senator Watson is referring, I do not know what that proposition is. However, I will seek a response from the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Community Services aware that many rumours have been circulating in north Queensland concerning the decentralisation of rehabilitation services? Can the Minister advise whether the Townsville rehabilitation centre will be retained, whether the services presently provided by the centre will be fully maintained and how the proposed reorganisation will affect the community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of articles in the Townsville Press, and I recently read an editorial in the Townsville Press, making assertions about what would happen to the rehabilitation centre in Townsville. Certainly the rehabilitation centre will be retained. The building is new and is useful for the purpose it serves, unlike many of the other rehabilitation centres throughout Australia which are inappropriately located and inappropriate for the sorts of services which the Government intends the Commonwealth rehabilitation service to provide. There will be a regionalisation of services, however. In north Queensland we will extend the network of rehabilitation teams from those that exist in Cairns and other areas to ensure that services are provided where the people are, rather than trying to drag people into existing services. In that reorganisation there will be some moving around of the professionals in the rehabilitation service to ensure that those services are accessible to the people they are meant to be for, but the Townsville centre will be retained.

ANSWER.PARA: Over the last three years the Townsville centre has been to the forefront in reorganising its activities. It has developed rehabilitation teams which are more appropriate to developing programs suited to individual clients, it has overcome some of the artificial structures which inhibited efficient rehabilitation in the past and in many ways it has been more advanced in progress in this area than most other centres in Australia. In doing that, already many of the changes we propose have been made in Townsville and we now anticipate that they will occur in other centres. The campaign that has been run in the Townsville media probably stems from some people who in the past have not wanted to see change and who resent the change that has occurred. The editorial I read seemed to be an attack on the local member, Mr Lindsay, which is completely unjustified. I can assure honourable senators that he has done nothing--

TALK.START.PARA: —He has done nothing at all; that is right.

—At least Mr Lindsay is known and is an advocate and a representative of the people who elected him, unlike the honourable senator who interjected, who is largely an advocate and a representative of a foreign power.
—Order! I ask Senator Grimes to withdraw the imputation in his answer in regard to Senator MacGibbon.
—I withdraw if the good senator finds it offensive. I can understand that he might find Mr Lindsay's attitude to his remarks offensive. It is just that he can dish it out and not take it.
—Lindsay will get rolled at the next election anyway.
—Order! The Minister was asked to withdraw by the Chair, not by Senator MacGibbon.

—We had better not enter into Senator Michael Baume's past in this place as we might not get through Question Time. However, the attack in the Townsville Bulletin was unfair to Mr Lindsay who, with Senator Reynolds, has been an advocate of the retention of the Townsville rehabilitation centre and the maintenance of the services there.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. I recognise that my question affects men as well as women but I hope that she will be able to answer it. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that single and divorced service men and women have no entitlement to full removals at government expense on reposting. Is this not a case of discrimination on the grounds of marital status and thus a contravention of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 and/or the Public Service Reform Act 1984? What action is the Government taking to rectify the situation?
—I am not aware whether the `facts' referred to in Senator Newman's question are facts. I will have those matters checked and seek advice so that the question can be answered.

—The Minister representing the Minister for Health will be aware of the tabling of the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985 entitled `Human Embryo Experimentation in Australia'. Can the Minister inform the Senate whether this report will receive timely consideration by the Government in order to enable a response to the Senate by the autumn session next year? Will the Government take into account the remarkable and encouraging fact that the report is totally consistent with the recommendations of the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe, held in Strasbourg only a week or so ago? I ask the Government also to bear in mind the salutary words of His Royal Highness the Prince of Wales at the Harvard 350th commemoration ceremony a month or so ago when he said that to avert disaster not only do we need to educate people to make things but we also need to produce people who have complete moral control over the things they make.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the tabling of the report. I could hardly be otherwise with Senator Tate as Chairman and chief publicity officer of that Committee. It is the policy of the Government to respond to all reports within a three-month period and that commitment will be honoured in this case. Advice will be provided to the Government by the Attorney-General and the Minister for Health. The Minister for Health is aware of the recommendations of the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe, held in September, and he has referred these recommendations to the Medical Research Ethics Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council for consideration at its next meeting. The Medical Research Ethics Committee has also undertaken to provide expert comment on the human embryo experimentation report and this advice will be with the Council of the NHMRC in November.

ANSWER.PARA: Republican that I am, I will convey the salutary words of the Prince of Wales to all my ministerial colleagues. I note that the Senate Select Committee must have been well aware of the remarks of the good Prince as both the majority and the dissenting reports rejected the passage of the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1984.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY: GOVERNMENT HOUSING LOANS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. On 24 September, in answer to a question by Senator Giles, the Minister referred to the people of Canberra as `self-indulgent, selfish and egocentric people who live in this Territory and have been sponging off the taxpayers for 20 years'. Given his Government's announcement to reverse its Budget decision to increase the interest rates for certain Commonwealth mortgages, can the people of Canberra expect an apology from the Minister for that outburst?

—In answer to one half of the honourable senator's question, a decision was made to obtain savings which had been sought in another matter. In answer to the other half of the question, I see no reason to revise my opinion about the citizens of this Territory.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry and the Treasurer. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in Wednesday's Canberra Times entitled `Big farmers group advises its members not to pay tax'? If so, can the Minister advise what the consequences would be for those people who accept this advice and do not pay the fringe benefits tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article referred to. Assuming that there was a tax liability, the consequences of not paying the tax, as Mr Kerin pointed out, could be imprisonment and would certainly be a heavy financial penalty. Mr Kerin also pointed out that the call was rather cunningly worded. It called upon members not to pay the tax by one means or another. Of course, one means by which anybody who had a previous fringe benefits tax liability could avoid paying the tax would be to cash out the benefit and thereby remove the liability. Under those circumstances there would be no liability and, therefore, no penalty.

ANSWER.PARA: I find one thing alarming about this sort of campaign, which was organised in this case by the Livestock and Grain Producers Association of New South Wales. It has long distressed me that farmers can be so readily enlisted as foot soldiers in political campaigns over issues which are of either little or no consequence to them or, on some occasions, actually to their disadvantage. I cite as one example the long agitation for the establishment of the Primary Industry Bank of Australia to make soft loans. Anybody who looks at the graphs tracing movements in land prices will see that immediately after the Bank opened for business in 1979 the price of land started climbing and it continued to climb until 1984 or thereabouts. The same can be said of the campaign against a capital gains tax, including the type of capital gains tax which this Government has introduced, that is, one which is applied only on real gains. It was very easy for political propagandists serving their own interests to enlist farmers in a campaign against a capital gains tax of that type. The reality is that over a long period the real price of agricultural land has moved little, if at all, and therefore a capital gains tax levied on real gains would have little, if any, relevance.

However, through that same period when soft loans from PIBA were helping to inflate land prices to unsustainable levels, farmers continued to buy land at excessive prices in the expectation of receiving untaxed capital gains. In other words, those two elements combined played the major role and were either substantially or possibly entirely responsible for the foolish escalation in land prices which took place throughout the early 1980s. Anybody who asks friends in banking, where people have direct knowledge of these matters, will find that, almost without exception, the reason why those farmers are insolvent today or are at risk of becoming insolvent is that they paid excessive prices for land in the early 1980s. In other words, over a long period farmers have had the misfortune of very bad leadership.

I regret that that continues and that they are being exploited yet again in this campaign over the fringe benefits tax. The plain fact is that the overwhelming majority of farmers will have little, if any, liability to pay fringe benefits tax.

If that campaign succeeds, the revenue of the FBT will fall short by something of the order of $600m in a full year. That will have to be recovered somewhere else or the tax cuts will have to be abandoned. If it were decided to recover it somewhere else, there are a number of potential areas where it could be recovered. One such area would be by terminating the full refund of excise on farm distillate, and that may well be what the National Party and the Liberal Party are contemplating doing because when they were in government there was not a full excise rebate on farm distillate. Perhaps that is what the Liberal and National parties are thinking of doing again; abolishing the fringe benefits tax and, in order partially to offset the revenue loss, abolishing the full rebate of excise on farm distillate. If that happened, if the Liberal and National Party policy were implemented, the farmers would be vastly more disadvantaged than they would be by a fringe benefits tax.

The National Farmers Federation President and his fellow Elders-IXL directors might well have a very sound personal interest in campaigning for the abolition of the fringe benefits tax, but that is certainly not in the interests of the people whom the National Farmers Federation President purports to represent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for Finance to the statements of his Western Australian Labor Party colleague, Premier Burke. After meeting with Mr Hawke, Mr Burke said: `I am quietly confident that we have been able to persuade him that the tax should not be imposed'. He was referring to the gold tax. I refer the Minister also to a statement by Mr Burke on radio this morning. After conceding that in a perfect world there might be a tax on gold, he went on to say that gold was a fragile bright spot that deserves to be fostered and not attacked by way of a tax at this time. I ask the Minister, in the light of those comments: Can we conclude that the Government will not proceed with the gold tax proposal?

—The Government has not made a decision on that issue. I expect, although I do not guarantee, that a decision will be made within the next month. Senator Chaney will have to contain his curiosity until that time. In contrast, of course, the general public will have to wait 12 or 18 months-perhaps forever-to find out what sort of fringe benefits tax the Opposition will impose. The general public might be told that the Opposition will enforce section 26 (e) of the Income Tax Assessment Act, and do it retrospectively.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. It is clear that the Minister has moved to debating the question. He answered the question very shortly and is now debating the issue. He should be sat down.
—Order! The Minister is getting into the realm of debate and I ask him to confine his answer.

—Certainly, Mr President. I expect that a Government decision on this issue will be made within the next month. Finally, I draw the attention of Senator Chaney to the West Australian newspaper of 9 August 1984, I think it was, which reported accurately Mr Howard saying that there ought to be a gold tax.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SOUTH PACIFIC NUCLEAR FREE ZONE TREATY

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs seen a statement that indicates that France is not prepared to sign the protocols to the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty? If so, can he advise us of the Government's response to this statement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that, according to a speech by the French Ambassador in Washington on 29 September, France is not prepared to sign the protocols to the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. The Government very much regrets that state of affairs. It is worth repeating that the Treaty is not anti-French but pro-region. It reflects the strong and united opposition of South Pacific countries to all nuclear testing in their region.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government also rejects the suggestion made in the Ambassador's speech that the Treaty is detrimental to Western interests in general. United States of America officials, by contrast, have consistently emphasised their appreciation of the efforts of the authors of the Treaty to ensure that vital Western interests are taken into account. The Government rejects the charge that the Treaty is anti-Western. The Treaty seeks to reinforce, not to undermine, the existing security situation in the South Pacific to which Australia's defence relationship with the United States has long contributed. The Treaty in no way impedes Australia's ability to co-operate militarily with Western allies-notably the United States under ANZUS-or to contribute to the main- tenance of stable nuclear deterrence.

—I was not sent the alleged document which was quoted in the Australian but I did read the newspaper article. In fact, I have personally told Senator Coates one area in which he is wrong. I do not know whether he agrees with me but he is still smiling and still talks to me.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Yesterday in a doorstop interview the Leader of the National Party, Mr Ian Sinclair, talked about providing a total exemption from fringe benefits. What would be the effect of such an exemption?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall quote the exact words used by Mr Sinclair. In response to the question:

ANSWER.PARA: Doesn't there have to be a tax in any sense on what some of your colleagues have admitted are rorts?
He said:
The only way to treat fringe benefits is to provide a total exemption, as we intend to do, in getting rid of this fringe benefits tax package.

I note that that contradicts what Mr Sinclair himself said last week. It contradicts what his Deputy Leader said last week. It contradicts what Mr Howard said six years ago, but then Senator Chaney contradicts that as well. I was asked what would be the consequences. The immediate consequences, of course, would be a revenue loss of the order of $600m in a full year. However, that figure would very rapidly grow because if there were a total exemption from fringe benefits tax there is no doubt that there would be an explosion in the rate at which income received in cash, and which is therefore taxable, would be converted into income paid in kind, which would be therefore specifically exempt from taxation, as Mr Sinclair suggests. The effect of that, of course, undoubtedly would be that the tax cuts which this Government will introduce on 1 December this year and 1 July next year could not be delivered unless taxes in some other form were vastly increased or outlays were reduced to the extent of-by that time-probably a couple of billion dollars. Probably half the income currently being received as taxable income would be converted into non-taxable fringe benefits. The revenue consequences of that would be $10 billion plus. That would be the figure before very long if fringe benefits were not taxed. Of course that will not actually be done because the Opposition, on its secret agenda-the one it will not talk about-has the silly belief that the Opposition could enforce section 26 (e) of the Income Tax Assessment Act to get at the income that has been evaded over many years. If the Opposition believes it could enforce section 26 (e) it has a moral and legal obligation to collect the tax which has been evaded over many years. The Opposition's secret agenda is to exempt fringe benefits from taxation but to apply section 26 (e). The Government has made the judgment that it is not feasible to do this and it stands by that judgment. But the Opposition believes it is possible. As I said, if the Opposition believes that this proposal on its secret taxation agenda can be enforced it has a moral and legal obligation to enforce it retrospectively.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Treasurer advise the Senate of the amount by which interest rates are inflated by the official support for the Australian dollar?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure precisely what Senator Brownhill means by the phrase `official support for the Australian dollar'. It is well known that the Reserve Bank of Australia has been operating in the market to some extent when it has believed the market rate to be temporarily aberrant and that, therefore, it ought to intervene. The bank's judgment on that question, particularly in the last couple of months, has been well and truly vindicated by what has happened. The bank was intervening when the dollar fell below 60c. ANSWER.PARA: What the bank is not doing, and has not done since the dollar was floated, is attempt to hold an exchange rate that is grossly misaligned with the underlying market reality. By a variety of regulatory devices the previous Government maintained the exchange rate at an artificially high level because that was the only policy it had to control inflation. It did not have a wages policy, so for years throughout the late 1970s and the early 1980s when John Howard was Treasurer, as a ghastly substitute for a wages policy it deliberately maintained an overvalued Australian dollar. That did enormous damage to Australian industry, both primary and secondary. I can only assume that if John Howard were ever in a position to have an influence on policy in this country again, that is what he would do. If Senator Brownhill is concerned about interest rates, I remind him that the highest interest rates ever recorded in Australia were recorded in April 1982 when the 90-day bank bill prime rate hit 22 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister disagree with recent Press statements to the effect that the Reserve Bank was most probably escalating interest rates by between 3 per cent and 4 per cent?
—Who made that statement?
—I do not know who made that statement.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the collection of around $600m next financial year from the fringe benefits tax to help finance the Government's tax package. I also refer to the Australian Bureau of Statistics survey which shows that a high share of all fringe benefits goes to high income earners. For example, of those in the top income brackets, 18 per cent get transport fringe benefits, compared with only 3 per cent in the bottom income bracket. Can the Minister say whether those liable to fringe benefits tax will tend to be those taxpayers in the community who are to receive a cut in their marginal tax rate from 60c in the dollar to 49c in the dollar?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The simple answer to the last part of the question is yes. Given that the receipt of fringe benefits tax is overwhelmingly concentrated in high income groups, one is dealing with the same group of people-not the same individuals in every case who are presently paying the 60c marginal tax rate, or at least when the tax reform package is completed would be paying the 60c marginal tax rate in the absence of any change to the tax rate scale. The fringe benefits tax revenue-the equation does not match one to one, but it is roughly equivalent-will be required to reduce the maximum marginal tax rate from 60c to 49c, so the two really are inseparable,

ANSWER.PARA: As Senator Messner said in an outburst of honesty just over 12 months ago when he wrote the minute of the official shadow Ministry meeting, it would be opportunistic and dishonest to support the goodies in the tax reform package-that is, lower marginal rates-while simultaneously opposing the nasties. Of course, Senator Messner was absolutely correct. It would be dishonest and hypocritical to do that and Senator Messner recommended that the Opposition should not do it. For quite a while the Opposition did not do that but since then, of course, the Leader of the Opposition, in his desperate attempt to maintain his leadership of the Liberal Party of Australia from the repeated challenges of the extra-parliamentary pretenders to the Liberal Party leadership, has opted for dishonesty and hypocrisy. He has done precisely what Senator Messner said just over a year ago that the Opposition should not do.

An illustrative example of the sorts of fringe benefits that were paid to a middle to high ranking executive was given, I think, by the Acting Treasurer, in the House of Representatives earlier this week. A representative sample of what is euphemistically called a salary package comprised: A salary of $45,000, which was taxable; a representative allowance of $3,000; $6,000 for superannuation; a leased Toyota Cressida, $5,800-if it was a Mercedes it would be more like $10,000; motor vehicle maintenance and running costs et cetera, almost $2,000; a hostess allowance, $4,000; a low interest loan, nearly $9,000; $3,000 for school fees; and $3,000 for holiday travel. That makes a total income of $115,000, of which only $45,000 is taxable.

What are euphemistically called salary packages of that type were not only reasonably common but also increasing at an alarming rate. Because they were fairly common and were rapidly becoming more common, a great deal of revenue that should have been collected in income tax was not collected. As Senator Maguire said, that is of the order of $600m which, as a rough equivalent, will be applied to reducing marginal tax rates for roughly the same group of people, but with this important difference: Those people who were honestly paying the tax on all the income received will be substantially better off. Those who were avoiding or evading paying tax on all the income received, through the conversion of a good deal of it to fringe benefits, will be worse off. They are the people who are squealing and they are the people whom Senator Messner and his colleagues represent.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. Is it a fact that approximately $140m will need to be paid by Government departments and statutory authorities in order to comply with the requirements of the fringe benefits tax? What are the administrative costs involved in collecting these moneys? Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a recent study by Professor John Rickard of the Melbourne Graduate School of Management, who concludes that as a result of the fringe benefits tax `the economy may face a significant decline in productivity and reduced government revenues' and that employees on higher value packages will end up being better off, while lower income earners will suffer? Does the Minister disagree with this assessment? If so, can he table any contrary private sector analyses?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have briefly glanced at the assessment, I think it was euphemistically called, done by some obscure academic, whose name I have forgotten, from the Melbourne Business School of Management, or something like that. Frankly, I thought it was not worth wasting too much time looking at it, but if Senator Alston would like a disciplined assessment of it, I will try to get one for him in the next couple of days. Regarding the earlier part of the question, I am not sure what the notional payment from the Commonwealth is. I thought it was something less than $140m, but I cannot recall for certain. The greater part of that, of course, is in defence. I think that estimate has been revised downward in defence from the order of $112m to something like $60m or $70m. I think the $140m figure should be revised accordingly.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the cost of collection, I thought that all the questions organised by the so-called Waste Watch Committee at the Senate Estimates committees should have provided the answer to that by now, unless they are too lazy to add the tables up or, perhaps, incapable of it. I remember that one or two departments were mentioned, one of which I think was the Department of Finance, although I cannot guarantee the absolute accuracy of this. The Department of Finance, when grilled by one of the Perry Masons of the Waste Watch Committee, was asked how much it would cost the Department to administer the fringe benefits tax and it said: `Something less than one half an ASL'-that is, something less than a half time job for one person in a department which has about 1,500 employees. In other words it is negligible. With the possible exception of the Department of Defence, I think that is true for the Public Service in general.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Am I to take it from the last part of the Minister's answer that neither he nor his Department has any idea of the approximate collection cost?
—Off the top of my head, no.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Community Services. Further to my question a couple of weeks ago regarding occasional care and the new guidelines recently announced by the Minister, can the Minister say whether there will be any funding cuts to neighbourhood houses in relation to their provision of child care for occasional users?
—It's a dorothy dixer.

—It is not, you know. The new occasional care guidelines, which were released at the same time as we announced we would provide more occasional care, take into account the fact that in some States such as South Australia occasional care centres are running neighbourhood houses. There is no reason in the world why, under the new guidelines, those centres should receive less funding. I have asked the Office of Child Care to look at that matter. One would expect that some of the centres which are a bit small and perhaps non-viable may want to increase their size to be more viable and get more adequate funding. However, the guidelines will not affect the funding of those neighbourhood centres in South Australia.
