DEBATE.TITLE: WILDLIFE PROTECTION (REGULATION OF EXPORTS AND IMPORTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion by Senator Ryan:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I have pleasure in leading the debate on the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1986 and to indicate from the outset that the Opposition will be supporting the Bill. This legislation makes a number of amendments, some of a minor technical nature and some of considerably more substance, to a piece of legislation originally enacted in 1982 which was itself one of the most significant environmental pieces of legislation introduced and pioneered by the former Liberal-National Party Government. The essence of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 was to give some domestic legislative underpinning for the so-called CITES Convention-the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species.

SPEECH.PARA: During the last few years a concerted attempt has been made on a world-wide basis to bring some regulation into the trade in animals, and into the trade in flora and fauna generally, and, in particular, to provide particular protection for endangered species and those species of plants and animals regarded as being in danger either of immediate extinction or very close to extinction. CITES works by having a number of separate appendices to the original convention in which animal and plant species are listed depending upon the degree to which they are endangered and particular protection is given to them.

The piece of legislation now before us seeks to make certain changes to the original legislation and I will briefly outline a number of them. The first is that it gives permission for a new system of export of Australian domestic pets. It is not what one might call a budget Bill; it is, however, very much a budgie Bill since the principal species to be given new status is budgerigars. The Bill will allow people to export their budgerigars provided that the budgerigars were originally bred in captivity, or for the purposes of captivity, and are not taken in the wild. So a new regime will be established to allow the export of domestic pets.

Secondly, there is a consolidation of the rules governing the export of invertebrates. Thirdly, there is a tidying up of the administrative procedure to allow multiple transactions, that is, to allow the consolidation of documents regarding the exportation of a large number of animals or plants under this regime without having to make a separate application on behalf of each one. Steps are taken to clarify the search procedures which are available to Customs officers and other officers to check on smuggling, and increased protection is afforded to witnesses when one comes to prosecutions and the various legal steps which may be taken under the Act.

One minor technical point is raised in the interpretation clauses of the legislation. It gives protection to animals which are of the class agnatha after pisces in the definition of the term `fish'. In the legislation the agnatha class is the so-called hagfish, a very primitive, jawless fish. I pause at this stage and decide not to reflect upon the Australian Democrats. There has been some considerable doubt as to whether they fall within the normal classification of pisces. Therefore they are separately provided for in this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —There should be a standing order against bad jokes in this place.

—If there were a standing order against bad jokes in this place the chamber would undoubtedly move at a far quicker pace than it does at the moment. The other point to which I draw attention is that over the course of 1985-86 some 2,500 permits and 312 authorities were issued under this Act. The permits relate to an individual document which has to be procured from the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service in order to allow the export of a plant or an animal which is otherwise afforded protection under the legislation. During 1985-86, 2,500 such permits were issued of which, interestingly, 1,439 were permits issued for the exportation of wildflowers, nearly all of which were exported from Western Australia. In the other categories, 654 permits were issued for the export of kangaroo products, 22 for the export of possums or mutton-birds, 145 for household pets, 60 for items used in scientific research, 110 for zoological displays, 25 for live animals for commercial interests, 26 for non-living animals for commercial interests and there were 19 private transactions. Three hundred and twelve authorities were issued of which 300 were issued for artificially propagated plants, 10 for scientific specimens and two for travelling circuses. This is indicative of the burden of work which is placed upon the Service in terms of the paper work required and which, hopefully, some of the technical amendments in the legislation, particularly in regard to the multiple transaction authorities, may help to pick up.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things which are undertaken in this piece of legislation relates to clause 5, which amends section 13 of the principal Act to ensure that live animal specimens can not only be sent from zoo to zoo, but also from a zoo to a relevant approved institution-which means an approved institution that is also a prescribed scientific organisation-and vice versa. Thus section 13 would be widened to provide for the transfer of specimens-for example, from Taronga Park Zoo to the Smithsonian Institute in Washington-so long as the other requirements of section 13 of the principal Act are satisfied.

I pause to say something very briefly about zoos and zoological institutions in general. Over recent years a great deal of analysis and a great deal of thought has been given to the role of zoos and zoological gardens in the whole wildlife and animal welfare debate. It is undoubtedly true that many people have become progressively more and more concerned about the keeping of animals in captivity generally and the keeping of them in zoos in particular. I do not believe that all the places which have established themselves as zoos have anywhere near the sorts of standards which ought to be maintained for the welfare of the animals concerned or, indeed, for the alleged educational and scientific purposes which are undertaken. Nevertheless, I do not go along with those people who seek to advance the proposition that there should be a total prohibition on zoos, wildlife parks and the like.

I will give three or four examples of the sort of work which can be done in zoological institutions. For instance, many people will be familiar with the work of Gerald Durrell and his establishment on the island of Jersey. One of the projects which he undertook was to try to rehabilitate the species of the Mauritius pink pigeon. There were about 10 known representatives of the species still in existence in Mauritius. Durrell took a breeding pair to his establishment in Jersey and eventually bred them up to a colony of 75 or so. He then took a large number of them back to Mauritius and re-released them into their original habitat where, from all reports, they are doing extremely well and the species has been brought back from the brink of extermination.

TALK.START.PARA: —Peter Pigott, too, with the Parma wallabies.

—Indeed, Peter Pigott's effort with Parma wallabies is one of the more local instances that can be given. Similarly, Pere David's deer, a species of deer which is now extinct in its original habitat in China, was bred up at Buckworth in the United Kingdom, and recently a number of individuals have been returned to China and re-established within their native environment.

SPEECH.PARA: It is certainly true that enormous numbers are not necessarily a guarantee of continued existence. For instance, in the early part of this century there were in the United States millions of passenger pigeons. The last example of the passenger pigeon, however, died in the Cincinnati zoo in 1913 or 1914. Earlier, only a few generations before that, as I say, passenger pigeons had been recorded practically in their billions, probably, throughout the whole of North America.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Tasmanian tiger?

—Whether the Tasmanian tiger is entirely extinct is certainly one of the intriguing questions in Australian wildlife at the moment. One keeps seeing reports that there have been sightings, that there is some evidence that the thylacine might still be in existence. One certainly hopes so. One certainly hopes that the considerable amount of work that is going on in Tasmania to try to verify this will prove to be successful.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that Australia could provide certain advantages as far as these sorts of programs are concerned. For instance, it has been put to me that it would be possible to try to bring from Sumatra a representative pair of Sumatran rhinoceroses in an attempt to re-establish them in Australia by allowing them to breed in more favourable conditions, with the hope that they could then be returned to the very small wildlife parks which are maintained on that island. I think that is the sort of contribution which could be made by Australia and Australian zoological institutions.

One ought to understand that the trade in animals is a very large trade. I shall say something about that and then make some comments about the very disturbing nature of criminal activity in the trade in animals. I believe that that is a matter which I should advert to only very briefly because both Senator Sanders and Senator Georges are present. The Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare is doing some extremely important work in investigating, at least from the Australian perspective, some of the allegations which have been raised.

The sorts of things people are prepared to pay for is extraordinary. For instance, Mexico has a very large trade, worth several million dollars a year to the Mexican Government, in the export of red-kneed tarantulas. Why anybody would want to keep or purchase red-kneed tarantulas is almost beyond me. Nevertheless, Mexico certainly makes a large amount of money each year by breeding up these creatures-which, I take it, are probably fairly objectionable sorts of beasts-and shipping them around the world. Sri Lanka makes about $20m a year from the export of tropical marine fish-mainly, I suppose, to aquariums and to people who want to have these pretty little things sitting on their desks in their offices, so that they have the chance to look at something which is permanently around with its mouth open and not actually asking for a rise. The Philippines exports some 400 tonnes of raw coral a year. It is certainly true that there is an enormous trade in animals in a place such as Zimbabwe, which earns just over $US6m from the export of wild animals-most of them in an exploitative fashion which we would regard as entirely inappropriate and improper. A very large contribution is made to Papua New Guinea's revenue by the breeding and export of butterflies.

There are areas which one would find most objectionable. For instance, the trade in ivory has now become one of the most barbaric trades imaginable. I cannot believe that civilised people in countries such as Australia would still actually be prepared to purchase ivory when they consider not only the way in which the ivory is obtained, but also the danger in which the ivory-bearing species throughout Africa is placed, which in recent years has led to the almost total devastation of the elephant populations in a number of countries. I suppose one becomes slightly concerned when, in order to provide the gourmands of Europe with their necessary supply of frogs' legs, in 1978 in India more than 10,500 tonnes of frogs were killed to yield 3,500 tonnes of frogs' legs to be supplied to restaurateurs and to alleged gastronomes in Europe. One really wonders about some of the things that human beings are prepared to do to animal species to satisfy what, after all, are fairly passing temptations. Nevertheless, the whole CITES convention has had some very considerable successes in limiting the excesses which have occurred in recent years in the killing of animals throughout the world.

I will raise a number of smaller matters very briefly. Senator Grimes's advisers might give him a piece of paper indicating a response. I will simply raise two issues and then come back to the question of some of the work that I understand is being done by the Senate Committee. One matter is that of the exportation of sea snake products. Each year, many thousands of sea snakes are caught up in fishing operations in the northern prawn fishery area. These sea snakes die as soon as the catch is brought aboard. The northern prawn fishery is very strictly controlled. It is controlled in terms of the number of operators, the nature of the boats and the boundaries in which the fleet can operate. There is also a closed season.

As an inevitable consequence of the operations of the northern prawn fishery a large number of sea snakes are taken in the catch. There has been some attempt by a firm-at least one in Townsville of which I am aware-to seek to make products out of the snake skins and export them. The National Parks and Wildlife Service, which has responsibility under this legislation, has prevented any export of sea snake products. It has advised that an adequate management program could not be put in place. I find this very difficult to come to grips with because if we are to have an effective regime for the management of Australian flora and fauna one thing which is absolutely necessary is that there be public understanding of what we are attempting to do and public support for the very important work which takes place under this legislation for the conservation of animals.

We have a situation in which a large number of sea snakes are condemned to die automatically as part of the controlled fisheries regime. The parks authority says: `I am sorry. The snakes are dead. There is nothing we can do about that but we will not allow you to make any useful products for export from those snake skins. We cannot prevent them being killed as an incidental consequence of the northern prawn fishery operations but we will not allow that to be turned into some commercial use'. That is the sort of dog-in-the-manger attitude which says that although the animals will die nothing can be done and an attempt cannot be made to commercially exploit them. Unless it can be demonstrated that the scientific base for that is absolutely unassailable, it will have the effect of weakening public support for the regime that one wants to have in place. That matter has to be addressed.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a problem that needs to be addressed.

—Senator Georges says that problems will arise, but the way to date that the National Parks and Wildlife Service has responded has not demonstrated that the problem is scientifically or ecologically based other than to say: `Sorry, it is too difficult. Therefore, you cannot proceed'.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point to which I will refer is the recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation in its second report of September 1976 on trafficking in fauna. That Committee recommended that there be controlled exports of certain Australian fauna and, in particular, that there be a controlled export program for Australian native birds. This is an enormous debate, certainly not one that should be opened up in full. It has been a matter of some litigation. Mr Ackroyd and his friends have been to the High Court of Australia. There has been considerable confusion about exactly what is the position.

A very sound argument has been put for the controlled export of certain species, particularly of what are regarded as pest native birds. Anybody who has seen the damage to a sunflower crop caused by cockatoos or the damage caused to some farmers by pest species of native birds would be impressed with the argument that one ought to look in an intelligent fashion at controlled export arrangements. That would be justified. There would have to be very strict quotas and approved export institutions, such as zoos. This would be a source of revenue for zoos. There would not be difficulties in establishing a system which could be policed whereby the only exporting authorities would be the zoos, which would be responsible for the identification and certification of individual animals being exported. The argument which is constantly thrown back that Customs officers cannot do the job would not be relevant. The principal thing that this would achieve quite simply is that it would be another step towards making more comprehensive our attack upon the illegal trade and the enormous amount of organised crime which is directly involved in the wildlife trade in Australia.

I asked a question on notice in September last year about the number of prosecutions which had occurred as a result of the detection of attempts to export illegally Australian native fauna. The answer was that until 30 June 1985 there was a total of four prosecutions relating to the illegal export of Australian native fauna. These prosecutions were for, firstly, the attempted export of five Australian native birds, for which the accused was placed on a two-year good behaviour bond; secondly, the export of 11 Australian native birds and the attempted export of five Australian native birds, for which the accused failed to appear and a bench warrant was issued for his arrest; thirdly, the export of approximately 20 Australian native reptiles, for which the defendant was convicted and fined a total of $800; and, fourthly, the attempted export of 18 Australian native reptiles, for which the accused was fined a total of $5,000.

Two things can be said. The resources provided by the Government for the detection and prosecution of offences against the legislation are woefully inadequate. Secondly, the penalties are woefully inadequate, particularly when one realises that what we regard as pest species of bird in Australia can be sold for thousands of dollars on the quite open market-let alone the black market-in the United States of America and elsewhere. Therefore, we are dealing with big money. It is not surprising that big criminals, including the famous `Big Vinnie' Terressa and others, have had direct involvement with attempts-attempts which are tied up with the drug trade, money laundering and all such operations-to traffic illegally in Australian flora and fauna.

I will not develop this argument further. There is a great deal that I could say but I understand that members of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare have done some very important work in this regard. Senator Sanders and Senator Brownhill will participate in the debate. Undoubtedly they will be able to make some contribution on that matter. That area of organised criminal activity needs the closest attention by Australian Government authorities.

As I said, the Opposition is pleased to give its support to this legislation. It is very proud of the fact that the original legislation was pioneered by the coalition parties when they were previously in government. It believes that the Act and the CITES convention to which it refers are working well and are important elements in the international attempts to preserve wildlife and to preserve flora and fauna throughout the world. We are pleased to give our support to this amending Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after `That', insert:
`this Bill be referred to the Select Committee on Animal Welfare for report by the first day of sitting in 1987, and that the Committee give particular attention to whether-

(a) the Bill would weaken the supervision of animal exports, such as by the delegation of powers by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, resulting in decisions to export being made by persons who are neither qualified nor informed to assess properly whether an export is in the best interests of the animal or human communities;
(b) the removal of the requirement for applications for permits to be gazetted would undermine basic democratic principles by denying the public any meaningful participation in permit decisions;

(c) at a time when our native fauna and flora is under ever-increasing threat, strong legislative steps should be taken to close loopholes in existing laws, rather than creating even greater opportunities for those who wish to over-exploit our native species; and
(d) there ought to be stronger supervision of the export of animals covered by the Convention on Trade in Endangered Species'.

This amendment has the purpose of referring the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1986 to the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare for report by the first day of sitting in 1987. I move this amendment for the reason that this is a very complicated and large field of endeavour. Australian wildlife is not now being adequately protected. The Animal Welfare Committee has been studying a number of issues and could bring its expertise to bear in this situation. I would like to see this Bill go before the Committee for that reason. We, as human beings, have a responsibility to look after the wildlife of this world. As sophisticated human beings and as advanced societies we have really lost touch with our environment. Human beings were not always so out of touch. The so-called primitive societies that existed for thousands and thousands of years in harmony with their environment knew full well the value of everything that surrounded them.

I have a quotation by Chief Sealth of the Duwamish Tribe of Washington State which I think bears repetition. Honourable senators may note that the principal town in Washington State is now called Seattle and it was named after Chief Sealth. In 1855 he wrote a letter to the President of the United States, in which he said:

Every part of the earth is sacred to my people. Every shining pine needle, every sandy shore, every mist in the dark woods, every clearing and humming insect is holy in the memory and experience of my people.

The white man is a stranger who comes in the night and takes from the land whatever he needs. The earth is not his brother but his enemy, and when he has conquered it, he moves on. He leaves his father's graves, and his children's birthright is forgotten.
All Things share the same breath-the beasts, the trees, the man. The white man does not seem to notice the air he breathes. Like a man dying for many days, he is numb to the stench.
What is man without the beasts? If all the beasts were gone, men would die from a great loneliness of spirit, for whatever happens to the beast also happens to man.

All things are connected. Whatever befalls the earth befalls the sons of earth. The whites, too shall pass-perhaps sooner than other tribes. Continue to contaminate your bed and you will one night suffocate in your own waste.

When the buffalo are all slaughtered, the wild horses all tamed, the secret corners of the forest heavy with the scent of many men, and the view of the ripe hills blotted by talking wires, where is the thicket? Gone.
Where is the eagle? Gone. And what is it to say good-by to the swift pony and the hunt, the end of living and the beginning of survival.

We, as sophisticated people, might laugh at that sentiment, but it really is central to our whole existence. We have the stewardship of the earth presented to us because of our technological development.

In an editorial to a newspaper we see that the radical Right, the fanatical Right, is now challenging the national parks system. It wants to get at the environment of the national parks, at the habitat of the animals. We were told on the news that the Aboriginal people gave the New Right permission to go there. This is utter nonsense. The Aboriginal people, of all people, know that they cannot give anyone permission to go on the land. They do not give away the land. The Aboriginal people know that the land belongs to itself. In fact the Aboriginal people-all of us-belong to the land. No one owns the land. I note that the H. R. Nicholls Society-the Hypocritical Rip-off Nicholls Society-had its origins in Tasmania-the poor, benighted little island of Tasmania which used to be a green oasis and which is presently ruled by people who have no appreciation of anything that Chief Sealth might have held dear. The H. R. Nicholls Society, in terms of the environment, has now turned its attention to an overall attack on everything that this nation holds dear. If we left it to the H. R. Nicholls Society it would have 12-year-old children working 14 hours a day for 20c a day digging up the front lawns of Parliament House and turning them into an open pit mine. These sorts of people must be stopped. I am glad to see that the Government has stated that they will not be allowed to operate in the Kakadu National Park.

It is interesting to note that the firm operating in Kakadu, Geopeko, is a member of a joint venture with Peko-Wallsend Ltd and EZ Industries Ltd. EZ Industries is owned by North Broken Hill Holdings Ltd, which is one of the biggest wood chippers in the country. Unfortunately, wood chipping takes a tremendous toll on animals. The clear felling operation completely eliminates populations of animals. Many of the animals that live in forests live in hollows in the trees. When the trees are chopped down most of the animals are either crushed in the fall or crushed by the machinery on what used to be the forest floor. Most of the animals that survive that are destroyed in the regeneration burns which take place after wood chipping. If they somehow survive the regeneration burns, they are then poisoned by the 1080 chemical or hunters are brought in to shoot them. So not only is this sort of operation going on in Kakadu but it continues to go on around the country. Frankly, there is very little protection under the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act afforded to animals in wood chip situations; in fact, there is no protection whatsoever.

The Animal Welfare Committee received a lot of evidence, and much of it would indicate that the present Wildlife Protection Act is not being properly enforced. We note that, independent of our findings, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, in the case of Fund for Animals v. Federal Government and Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service, found that Queensland's 1985 kangaroo management program was very deficient. It found that the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service was interpreting the Act in line with its own long standing precedents rather than in the spirit of the parliamentary Act. The findings contained heavy criticism of the role of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and its administration of the Act.

This Bill specifically loosens up many of the requirements of the previous Act. In doing so it allows many of the procedures to go on in a more unchecked manner. Proposed new section 42a provides in part for a new type of export permit. This permit would be available to any person who engaged in multiple transactions, provided that the animals exported are bred in captivity or taken under an approved management program. Any person may apply for and be granted a permit which may remain in force for 12 months. This proposed amendment has profound ramifications for the kangaroo culling program. It would mean that exporters of kangaroo products need apply only for a multiple transaction permit which may be valid for 12 months. I feel that we need to tighten up on the permit procedures rather than loosen them, because already great liberties are being taken with permits. Under the Freedom of Information Act it was revealed that a number of dealers operating in Victoria were using the same permit number. Checks were not being made, in that case.

In our hearings we heard open testimony from a number of people. One group was the Customs Officers Association of Australia. We were appalled to find that less than a handful of the many containers that leave Australia every year are actually checked. From memory, only one container, containing kangaroo skins, was even questioned. It was not opened, it was merely questioned because the paperwork was not correct. The Customs Officers Association declared to us that, since it took five working man-days to load and unload a container, the containers were simply not checked. There are no controls in Australia, or very few, over outgoing animal products or fauna. We were told that Customs felt that its duty was to control incoming goods and that other countries would have Customs officers who would do the same for their country. They did not feel it was their duty to check outgoing goods.

The States which are engaging in the commercial kill of kangaroos are flouting their own wildlife Acts by taking advantage of section 92 of the Constitution, which allows free trade between the States. This free trade between the States makes it very difficult to determine how many kangaroos actually are being taken. In 1985, 1,343,167 Queensland kangaroo skins entered the trade in New South Wales. In addition, 1,595,000 kilograms of kangaroo meat and 218,000 kangaroo carcasses from Queensland entered the trade in New South Wales in that year. Up to December 1985, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, Queensland had exported 403,005 pickled skins and 37,377 raw skins. The commercial quota for Queensland in 1985 was 1,080,000. This is 703,549 fewer skins than the quota. So, are there multiple skins in Queensland? Do Queensland animals have more than one skin? I doubt it. Therefore, there is a tremendous discrepancy in the numbers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Queensland politicians do.

—Senator Puplick says that Queensland politicians have multiple skins. This is yet to be determined. Recently an article in the Sydney Morning Herald stated that 600,000 illegal skins were found in New South Wales. In testimony before us, the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service admitted that it did not know how many illegal kangaroos are taken every year. Furthermore, it does not feel that it is significant in terms of its own setting of quotas. It is obvious that a lot of question marks surround the taking of wildlife in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Further concern relating to this proposed new section is specific to koalas. It would eliminate the requirement that the designated authority be satisfied that the recipient is equipped to provide suitable care for each animal exported. It would effectively eliminate ministerial concern and the need for approval for a period not exceeding 12 months. On the import side, proposed new section 42b provides that any person may import specimens without being required to produce any particulars prior to, or on import, provided that the recipient is an approved institution requiring the specimens for research.

Research itself is coming under scrutiny by the Animal Welfare Committee. The vexed question of animal experimentation is just now being undertaken by the Committee. We have been travelling around the country looking at animal houses and at the role of the ethics committees in the various universities. I think this area of the Bill needs to be closely looked at to ensure that whatever experimentation is conducted is conducted in such a way that it will be humane and not harmful to the animal. It must not be inhumane to the animal. Furthermore, it must be necessary. We have already received evidence that some of the animal experimentation going on is simply not needed. This area is not addressed at all in the Bill.

Less stringent control on wildlife trade at Australian boundaries is potentially dangerous in light of the increased traffic in fauna associated with the drug trade. Senator Puplick has already mentioned the extent of the drug trade. We on the Animal Welfare Committee frankly do not feel that we are capable of dealing with this situation. We would very much like to see a body such as the National Crime Authority look into this aspect. Basically, we are set up to look at the welfare of the animals themselves. Certainly, it is a major consideration. The routes which are used to ship wildlife from Australia are also used to ship drugs back into the country on the back haul, and it is a problem.
